([[Chairman]], [[Board of directors|Board of Commissioners]]) | industry = [[Sport industry|Sports]] | products = [[Football team|Football club]] | revenue = {{increase}} [[Euro|€]] 118 million (2017)http://financials.morningstar.com/income-statement/is.html?t=AJAX®ion=nld&culture=en-US |operating_income={{increase}} [[Euro|€]] 69 million (2017)http://financials.morningstar.com/income-statement/is.html?t=AJAX®ion=nld&culture=en-US |net_income={{increase}} [[Euro|€]] 49 million (2017)http://financials.morningstar.com/income-statement/is.html?t=AJAX®ion=nld&culture=en-US |assets={{decrease}} [[Euro|€]] 26.0 million (2012) |equity={{increase}} [[Euro|€]] 103.5 million (2012) |num_employees = 339 (December 2012) | homepage = [http://www.ajax.nl/ Ajax.nl] }} '''AFC Ajax NV''' is mostly known as a [[Football team|football club]]. Since 17 May 1998 the club is registered as a [[Naamloze Vennootschap]] (N.V.) listed on the stock exchange [[Euronext]] Amsterdam. As a company the club strives to make a profit through ticket sales, as well as through income accumulated by competing in National, Continental as well as Global [[Association football|football]]. Half of the [[revenue]] is generated through club [[merchandise]], [[advertising]], and income from selling [[broadcasting|broadcasting rights]].{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/financials/financials.asp?ticker=AJAX:NA |title=AFC Ajax NV 2012 Annual Report, Filing Date Feb 23, 2013 |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek |accessdate =September 2, 2013}} Ajax is the only Dutch club with an [[initial public offering]] (IPO). Outside the Netherlands in countries such as the UK, Germany, Italy or Turkey there are more football clubs with IPOs, including the most successful of them all, [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], who are accredited with advising Ajax Amsterdam to enter the [[stock market]]. Several members of Ajax [[Board of directors|Board of Commissioners]] have a financial background in trade. For example, former [[treasurer]] of the club [[Arie van Os]] was a famous [[stockbroker]] from Amsterdam, who had worked for [[Van der Moolen]].{{cite web |url=http://vorige.nrc.nl/sport/ajax/article1882997.ece |title=God van de handel liet Ajax in de steek |publisher=NRC.nl |accessdate=2008-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202125824/http://vorige.nrc.nl/sport/ajax/article1882997.ece |archivedate=2014-02-02 |df= }} Only a limited amount of the shares in AFC Ajax NV are publicly traded on the Stock Market. The "Vereniging AFC Ajax" ({{lang-en|AFC Ajax Association}}) retain 73% of the shares. The following majority share holders are Insurance company [[Delta Lloyd Group]] with 9.95%, followed by former Stockbroker Adri Strating with 8.65%.{{Cite web |url=http://wiebezit.nl/afc-ajax-n-v-.html |title=Majority shareholders of AFC Ajax N.V. |access-date=2013-09-05 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304044733/http://wiebezit.nl/afc-ajax-n-v-.html |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} == History == {{Main|History of AFC Ajax}} In 1900, [[Floris Stempel]], Carel Reeser and Johan Dade founded the [[AFC Ajax|Amsterdamsche Football Club Ajax]] in [[Amsterdam]]. In 1911, Ajax moved into its first stadium [[Het Houten Stadion]] playing to the max capacity of 15,000. The funding for the stadium came from Wim Eggerman, a local businessman, and president of the club at the time.{{cite web |url=http://www.metronieuws.nl/regionaal/5-historische-ajax-plekken/SrZljo!MOHCqK7yI0pkQ/ |title=5 historische Ajax-plekken |publisher=Metro Nieuws |accessdate=2013-08-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308022734/http://www.metronieuws.nl/regionaal/5-historische-ajax-plekken/SrZljo!MOHCqK7yI0pkQ/ |archive-date=2014-03-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 1922, Ajax expanded into [[baseball]] as one of the founding clubs of the newly formed [[Honkbal Hoofdklasse]], the team won the national title four times, before the club shut down its baseball division exactly 50 years later. In 1934, Ajax relocated to a new stadium [[De Meer Stadion]], playing to an increased capacity of 22,000. The stadium was designed and funded by [[Architect]] and Ajax [[Board of directors|Commissioner]] [[Jordanus Roodenburgh]], who had designed and completed the first stadium for Ajax as well. Ajax also played their International fixtures at the [[Olympic Stadium (Amsterdam)|Olympic Stadium]] in Amsterdam to an increased capacity of 64,000.{{cite web|url=http://dare.uva.nl/document/52848 |title=De Meer |publisher=Universiteit van Amsterdam|accessdate=2013-08-30}} In 1964, [[Jaap van Praag (sports director)|Jaap van Praag]] was made the new chairman of the club, a position he held until 1978. The period during his tenure is widely considered Ajax most glorious, with the club winning the intercontinental title, as well as the continental title three years in a row from 1971–1973. In 1972, Ajax won the [[Eredivisie]] league title, the Dutch Cup, the European Cup, the European Super Cup and the Intercontinental Cup all in the same calendar year, also completing the European Cup treble the following year. In 1989, [[Michael van Praag]], the son of Jaap, became the new chairman of Ajax, a position he held until 2003. The club won the UEFA Cup in 1992 and the UEFA Champions League in 1995, winning the Intercontinental Cup once more the same year under his guidance. In 1996, construction was completed of a new soccer specific stadium, the [[Amsterdam ArenA]] to an increased capacity of 53,052. AFC AJax NV own 13% of the new stadium, which includes a training facility [[Sportpark De Toekomst]], itself with a capacity of 5,000. The remaining proprietorship of the stadium is held by the [[Government of Amsterdam]]. In 1998, AFC Ajax NV was created as the club registered as a [[Naamloze vennootschap]] company and were listed on the stock exchange [[Euronext]] Amsterdam on May 17 of that year.{{cite news|url=http://listofcompanies.co.in/afc-ajax-nv/ |title=Ajax opent voetbalacademie in Griekenland|publisher=List of Companies: AFC Ajax N.V.|date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=2013-09-03}} In 1999, AFC Ajax NV acquired 51% proprietorship of newly founded [[Ajax Cape Town F.C.]], through a merger of previous clubs Seven Stars and Cape Town Spurs, as AFC Ajax NV expanded their operations to South Africa. The remaining shares of the club were divvied between the Comitis family and the minority share holders the Efstathiou family. That same year on 18 June 1999, AFC Ajax NV acquired 51% shares of [[Ashanti Gold SC]], a West-African football club from Ghana, with [[Ashanti Goldfields Corporation]] retained 49% proprietorship of the club.{{cite web | url=http://www.modernghana.com/sports/90594/2/ashantigold-sporting-club-sponsors-brief.html | title=Ashantigold Sporting Club -Sponsors Brief |work=Ajax.nl|date=22 November 2005 |accessdate= 2013-05-02 }} In 2000, AFC Ajax NV acquired 72,5% of the shares of Belgian club [[K.F.C. Germinal Beerschot|Germinal Beerschot]] with whom Ajax had formed a parternship a year earlier.{{cite web|url=http://www.ajax.nl/web/show/id=154417/contentid=13351 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120530164834/http://www.ajax.nl/web/show/id=154417/contentid=13351 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 May 2012 |title=Ajax vergroot belang in Germinal Beerschot Antwerpen |language=Dutch |work=Ajax.nl |date=14 November 2001 |accessdate=2013-05-02 }} In 2003, AFC Ajax NV sold all of its shares in [[K.F.C. Germinal Beerschot|Germinal Beerschot]] back to Belgian businessman Jos Verhaegen for the symbolic price of €1, ending the fusion of both clubs and their joint operations.{{cite web|url=http://217.118.160.21/(/financien/rtlz/nieuws/)/components/financien/rtlz/2003/03_maart/13-ajax_gba_1euro.xml |title=Ajax verkoopt belang in Germinal voor 1 euro |language=Dutch |work=RTL Z |date=13 March 2003 |accessdate=2013-05-02 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Ajax also sold their shares of [[Ashanti Gold SC]] back to Ashanti Goldfields.{{cite web|url=http://www.ajax.nl/web/show/id=154417/contentid=27266 |title=Ajax zet financiële participatie in Ashanti Goldfields om in technische samenwerking |language=Dutch |work=Ajax.nl |date=14 February 2003 |accessdate=2013-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313144559/http://www.ajax.nl/web/show/id%3D154417/contentid%3D27266 |archivedate=2012-03-13 |df= }} Instead Ajax expanded operations to Orlando, Florida, in the United States, forming Ajax America, as well as the [[Ajax Orlando Prospects]] competing in the USL Pro league, before the North American club folded in 2007. In 2011, AFC Ajax NV opened the [[Ajax Hellas Youth Academy]] in Greece, in conjunction with George Kazianis and All Star Consultancy forming the first Ajax youth academy outside the Netherlands. Together they opened a total of 15 youth teams in Greece and Cyprus.{{cite news|url=http://www.ad.nl/ad/nl/1441/Ajax/article/detail/1898817/2011/03/15/Ajax-opent-voetbalacademie-in-Griekenland.dhtml |title=Ajax opent voetbalacademie in Griekenland|publisher=AD.nl|date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=2013-04-27}} == Locations == AFC Ajax manufacture and market their products worldwide. === Europe === *World Headquarters and EMEA Operations: [[Amsterdam]], [[Netherlands]] *Management Office: [[Nea Smyrni]], [[Greece]] === Africa === *African Headquarters: [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]] === North America === *American Headquarters: [[New York City]], [[United States]] AFC Ajax' subsidiaries employed 339 people in 2012 and achieved sales of €104.1 million. == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.hoovers.com/company-information/cs/company-profile.AFC_Ajax_NV.46101384cd08980e.html AFC Ajax NV Company Information] at Hoovers *[https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/AJAX:NA/news AFC Ajax NV Headlines & Press Releases] at Bloomberg {{AFC Ajax}} {{AFC Ajax Board}} [[Category:AFC Ajax]] [[Category:Companies established in 1998]] [[Category:Companies based in Amsterdam]] [[Category:Multinational companies headquartered in the Netherlands]] [[Category:1998 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Companies listed on the Euronext exchanges]] [[Category:Publicly traded sports companies]] [[Category:Naamloze vennootschappen]]

'''Alejandro M. Castillero Pinilla''' (born 1972 in [[Chitré]], [[Panama]]) is an [[lawyer|attorney]], [[real estate]] investor, [[shareholder]] of Nazareno Livestock Cattle Ranch, and founding partner of [https://web.archive.org/web/20120304071504/http://haoodnla.com/article/lxy09218424y9j01/250386 Castillero & Castillero] [[law firm]] in Chitré, the capital of the [[Herrera Province|province of Herrera]], on the [[Azuero Peninsula]] of Panama.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.radiopanama.com.pa/oir.aspx?id=827513|title=Alejandro Castillero director de PRONAT designado habla en Radio Panamá sobre los planes de trabajo que desarrollará al llegar a la institución.|access-date=2018-09-27}}</ref>
In August 2009, Castillero was named Technical Coordinator of [http://www.dgmarket.com/tenders/adminShowBuyer.do~buyerId=1347235 PRONAT] — the National Land Administration Program, the sole government entity responsible for facilitating the titling process in Panama — by Panama President [[Ricardo Martinelli]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.presidencia.gob.pa/ver_nodo.php?cod=550|title=Títulos de propiedad entrega PRONAT en La 24 de Diciembre|date=2009-10-23|website=www.presidencia.gob.pa|access-date=2018-09-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317053825/http://www.presidencia.gob.pa/ver_nodo.php?cod=550|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-03-17|df=}}</ref> Since that time, under the Martinelli administration, he and his PRONAT team have, on average, titled more than 2,500 properties per month.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tupolitica.com/cambio-democratico-panama/ricardo-martinelli-visita-azuero.html/|title=Ricardo Martinelli visita Azuero |work= TuPolitica.com - El Sitio y Centro de Prensa Oficial de la Política en Panamá |language=es|access-date=2018-09-27}}</ref>
Financed by [[Inter-American Development Bank]]), the extent of this [[land titling]] initiative is unprecedented for the Central American country, and is critical to achieving the Panama federal government’s goal of titling the entire country within five years to accelerate [[investment]] opportunities nationwide.
The impact of Castillero’s and his team’s early work at PRONAT came to fruition on December 31, 2009 when [http://www.panama-guide.com/article.php/analysis-new-law-80-rop-land-titles Law 80] was passed, facilitating possessory rights and free land titles across the Panamanian [[coastal zone]]s and [[island]]s. These regions, incidentally, are home to many [[indigenous people]]s, whose agrarian livelihoods render most unable to pay even modest amounts for the titles that stand to name them rightful owners of land which, in most cases, has sustained their families for generations.
With this in mind, PRONAT made titles for properties of five hectares or less available free-of-charge to the possessor. For those who wish to title more than five hectares — or buy currently unoccupied untitled land from the government — a price table, based on property location and size, is included in the law, alleviating discrepancies and legal confusion.
Castillero earned his Law and Political Science degree from [http://usmapanama.com/ Santa Maria La Antigua University] in [[Panama City]], Panama, and later, a master's degree in international banking and financial law from [[Boston University]], USA.
Castillero has held many important posts throughout his career, namely, National Director of Copyrights at the [https://web.archive.org/web/20101103065503/http://meduca.gob.pa/ Ministry of Education], Legal Advisor to the http://www.fao.org/countryprofiles/index.asp?lang=en&iso3=PAN Agriculture Affairs Committee] of the [[National Assembly of Panama|National Legislative Assembly]], and Legal Advisor to the [http://www.superbancos.gob.pa/home_eng.asp Superintendency of Banks].
Castillero stepped down in 2009 as CEO of [http://www.cascorrealty.com Cascor Realty] to accept his public position as Director of PRONAT, but remains active in various [[Philanthropy|philanthropic initiatives]] and [[charitable organization]]s. Alejandro is a founding member of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20110708165714/http://district5690.clubwizard.com/IMUpload/ACF3169.pdf Rotary Club of Chitré], Treasurer of the Herrera sub-Program of The [[Special Olympics]], and President of the Eneida Moreno de Castillero Foundation, a local organization dedicated to advancing the [[public welfare]] of the province of Herrera and the entire Azuero region.

'''Alexandra Waluszewski''' (born 1956) is a Swedish [[organizational theorist]], Professor at the Department of Economic History of the [[Uppsala University]], particularly known for her work with [[Håkan Håkansson]] on "Managing Technological Development"<ref>Möller, Kristian, and Senja Svahn. "Managing strategic nets a capability perspective." ''Marketing Theory'' 3.2 (2003): 209-234.</ref> and "Knowledge and innovation in business and industry."<ref>Baraldi, Enrico, Espen Gressetvold, and Debbie Harrison. "Resource interaction in inter-organizational networks: Foundations, comparison, and a research agenda." ''Journal of Business Research'' 65.2 (2012): 266-276.</ref>
== Life and work == In 1983 Waluszewski obtained her BS in Business Studies at the [[University of Uppsala]], where in 1989 she also obtained her PhD in Business Studies with the thesis, entitled "Framväxten av en ny mekanisk massateknik - en utvecklingshistoria" (The Emergence of a New Mechanical Pulping Technique—A Development Story) under guidance of [[Håkan Håkansson]].
Waluszewski serves her academic career at the [[Uppsala University]], where she was appointed Associate Professor in Industrial Marketing in 1997. In 2008 she is appointed Professor at the Department of Economic History of the [[Uppsala University]]. She is also Research Director of the Universities program entitled Uppsala Science, Technology Business.
Waluszewski research interest focussed on the question "how knowledge and technology is developed and utilized in business and industry, as well as how the understanding of these processes."<ref>Sharon Rider, Ylva Hasselberg, Alexandra Waluszewski (2012) ''Transformations in Research, Higher Education and the Academic Market.'' 2011. p. 216.</ref> In 2010 she is elected member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences]], and she is affiliated with the [[Industrial Marketing and Purchasing Group]].

Chairman, [[Manchester Giants (1975–2001)|Manchester Giants]] | notable_works = }} '''Amer Mouaffac Al Midani'''{{cite web |title=Louis Doyle |url=http://www.kingschambers.com/people/barristers/louis_doyle/ |publisher=Kings Chambers |accessdate=22 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115163821/http://www.kingschambers.com/people/barristers/louis_doyle/ |archivedate=15 January 2012 |df= }} (1957 – April 2012) was a member of the board of English [[association football|football]] club [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] from 1987 to 2002 and chairman of the [[Manchester Giants (1975–2001)|Manchester Giants]] [[basketball]] team.{{cite news |title=Ex-director passes away |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Club-News/2012/Apr/manchester-united-reports-sad-passing-of-former-club-director.aspx |work=ManUtd.com |publisher=Manchester United |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=22 August 2012 }} Born in [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]], to a Lebanese property developer,{{cite web |author=bar-knee |title=Midani a naughty boy? |url=http://www.mail-archive.com/newslist@rednews.co.uk/msg00587.html |publisher=Red News |date=27 March 2002 |accessdate=22 August 2012 }} he was a Lebanese junior [[table tennis]] champion at the age of 15, and moved to England at 18. By the mid-1980s, he had become chairman of the [[Manchester Giants (1975–2001)|Warrington Vikings]] basketball team. In 1985, he received an approach from Manchester United FC chairman [[Martin Edwards]], who wished to make Manchester United into a multi-sport club; as part of the deal, the Vikings moved from [[Warrington]], [[Cheshire]], to the Stretford Sports Centre in [[Trafford]], [[Greater Manchester]], changed its name to Manchester United Basketball Club, and Al Midani received a seat on the Manchester United board as well as shares in the club. He remained involved with the basketball club even after they separated from Manchester United and became the Manchester Eagles (and subsequently the Manchester Giants), but had left the club by the time it folded in 2001. In 1991, Al Midani attempted a takeover bid of Manchester United as part of a consortium that included club director and former player [[Bobby Charlton]] and would have installed Charlton as chairman, but was put off by Edwards' asking price of £30 million.McKinstry (2002), pp. 357–8 He retained his shares in the club through its flotation on the [[London Stock Exchange]] later that year, but in 1997, Al Midani sold 500,000 shares in Manchester United (0.77% of the club) at around £6 each, causing an 11.5p drop in the share price.{{cite news |first=John |last=Willcock |title=NatWest Markets offers graduates useful advice |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/natwest-markets-offers-graduates-useful-advice-1256778.html |work=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print |date=19 June 1997 |accessdate=22 August 2012 }} In 2002, he left the Manchester United board and was declared bankrupt after running up over £2 million of gambling debts in four days at the Rio hotel in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]].{{cite news |title=Soccer boss bankrupt from gambling debts |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1403361/Soccer-boss-bankrupt-from-gambling-debts.html |work=The Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |date=2 August 2002 |accessdate=22 August 2012 }} He was also a 12 per cent shareholder in Bobby Charlton Enterprises, the main company behind the Bobby Charlton Soccer School and Charlton's ventures into "lunches with legends".McKinstry (2002), p. 427 He died in April 2012. ==References== ;Bibliography *{{cite book |first=Leo |last=McKinstry |title=Jack & Bobby: A story of brothers in conflict |publisher=Willow |year=2002 |isbn=978-0007118762 }} ;Specific {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Midani, Amer}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:Lebanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Manchester United F.C. directors and chairmen]]

revision.text: '''Article 4 of the European Convention on Human Rights''' prohibits [[slavery]] and [[forced labour]]. Conscription, national service, prison labour, service exacted in cases of emergency or calamity, and "normal civic obligations" are excepted from these definitions. {{Cquote|Article 4 – Prohibition of slavery and forced labour 1. No one shall be held in slavery or servitude. 2. No one shall be required to perform forced or compulsory labour. 3. For the purpose of this article the term "forced or compulsory labour" shall not include: :a. any work required to be done in the ordinary course of detention imposed according to the provisions of Article 5 of this Convention or during conditional release from such detention; :b. any service of a military character or, in case of conscientious objectors in countries where they are recognised, service exacted instead of compulsory military service; :c. any service exacted in case of an emergency or calamity threatening the life or well-being of the community; :d. any work or service which forms part of normal civic obligations.}} ==Violations found== *Siliadin v. France, application No. 73316/01 (adjudicated in 2005; case of [[Indentured servitude|servitude]] and forced or compulsory labour){{Cite news|url=https://www.coe.int/en/web/impact-convention-human-rights/-/14-year-old-girl-kept-in-domestic-servitude-in-paris|title=Human trafficking criminalised after 14-year-old girl kept in domestic servitude in Paris|work=Impact of the European Convention on Human Rights|access-date=2018-06-21|language=en-GB}} *Rantsev v. Extruders for continuous production of pharmaceutical powders |revenue = |operating_income = |net_income = |num_employees = 350 |parent = |subsid = |homepage = http://www.bakerperkins.com |footnotes = }} '''Baker Perkins Ltd''' is a British engineering company based in [[Peterborough]] offering manufacturing and process services to the [[food industry]] throughout the world. ==History== The company has its origins with [[Jacob Perkins]] (1766-1849), an American inventor who moved to England in 1819 from [[Massachusetts]]. His son, [[Angier March Perkins]] (1799-1881), founded the firm of A. M. Perkins & Co Ltd to manufacture his inventions.http://www.hevac-heritage.org/victorian_engineers/perkins/perkins.htm In 1893, the company merged with Werner & Pfleiderer (London) to form Werner, Pfleiderer & Perkins Ltd. In 1904, WP&P moved their manufacturing from London to [[Westwood, Peterborough]]. In 1914, owing to pressure over its German-sounding name, the company became Perkins Engineers Ltd. During [[World War I]], the company produced a range of armaments including [[Harry Ricardo|Ricardo]] engines for [[Mark IV tank]]s.http://www.westwoodworks.net/HowItWas/WestwoodWorksInWW1/index.htm In 1918 it merged with [[Joseph Allen Baker|Joseph Baker]] & Sons Ltd of [[Willesden]] to become Joseph Baker Sons & Perkins Ltd and in 1923, Baker Perkins Ltd. By the time of the merger, Baker and Perkins were well-established names in the bakery, biscuit, confectionery, chocolate and chemical machinery industries. Just as the companies combined, the Bakers bought a factory in [[Saginaw]], Michigan, that for over 60 years was the base for manufacture of food and chemical equipment in North America. Between the wars, the company manufactured a wide range of machinery including laundry equipment. In 1939, Baker Perkins was asked to take on production of the new [[QF 6 pounder 10 cwt gun|twin 6-pounder coast defence gun]] and also made components for a wide range of other artillery pieces.http://www.westwoodworks.net/HowItWas/WestwoodWorksInWW2/index.htm#7 Post war, Baker Perkins specialised in equipment for the food processing and printing industries. ==Later Mergers== The business had expanded to become global in its organisation and sales when in 1987 the dairy and liquid food specialist, [[APV plc|APV]], acquired it. During this time the company relocated from old premises near the centre of Peterborough to a new purpose-built facility on the outskirts. In 2006 Baker Perkins regained its historical name and its independence when it was acquired by private investors. Most recently, Baker Perkins has introduced new moulding and forming technology for bread; developed equipment allowing confectioners to develop candies and lollipops; and pioneered technology expanding the variety of snacks and breakfast cereals.[http://www.bakerperkins.com/about-us/the-baker-perkins-story/ www.bakerperkins.com/about-us/the-baker-perkins-story] Detailed history of Baker Perkins Baker Perkins currently operates in two office locations, the headquarters being in [[Paston, Peterborough|Paston]], [[Peterborough]] with a second office in [[Grand Rapids]], Michigan.http://www.bakerperkins.com/contact/ ==Trade Associations== Baker Perkins maintains close links to the industries it serves through membership of key trade associations and research organisations. These include [[AACC International]], PMCA,http://www.pmca.com/membershiplisting.asp BEMA and B&CMA in the US: and the Leatherhead Food Internationalhttp://www.leatherheadfood.com/member-services-member and [[Brewing Industry Research Foundation|Campden BRI]] in the UK. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.bakerperkins.com}} * [http://www.bphs.net Baker Perkins Historical Society] * [http://www.westwoodworks.net Westwood Works 1903 - 2003] [[Category:Engineering companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Companies based in Peterborough]] [[Category:Food industry]] {{England-company-stub}}

'''Bernard A. Flynn''' (born 8 January 1964) is a serial entrepreneur, businessman and investor. He founded a number of advisory companies focused on value creation{{what|date=December 2017}} and growth for corporate clients.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/regionals/droghedaindependent/news/mccullen-signs-up-for-katawave-35394419.html|title=Irish Independent|website=www.independent.ie}}</ref> These companies operate mainly in the areas of strategy, optimisation, [[innovation]] and creativity, working across many sectors in Europe, Asia and the Americas.
He is founder of Katawave, BeChange, Red Planet, Promech, Ideaz, Black Swan Global, Synecco and is a principal investor in Grid Finance.<ref>{{Cite interview|url=http://irishtechnews.ie/business-needs-reimagination-i-want-them-to-succeed-not-just-survive-bernard-flynn/|title=Business needs reimagination, I want them to succeed not just survive. Bernard Flynn – Irish Tech News|website=irishtechnews.ie|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-25}}</ref>
He is now focussed on disrupting current business models by leveraging [[blockchain]], [[Cryptocurrency|cryptocurrencies]], [[virtual reality]], [[augmented reality]] the power of the crowd, [[Digital data|digital]], and the role of [[Startup company|startups]].
Flynn is a sponsor of the cross Atlantic challenge.<ref>http://crossrugbylegends.com/bernard-flynn/</ref><ref name="connections">{{Cite news|url=http://makingconnections.ie/ironman-with-a-heart/|title=Ironman with a Heart! - Making Connections|date=2016-08-15|work=Making Connections|access-date=2017-11-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
He has also been cited as an original [[Ironman Triathlon|ironman]] challenger.<ref name="connections" />
== Business career == Flynn pioneered [[Lean manufacturing|Lean Optimisation]] and [[Innovation]] [[Consultancy House|consultancy]] companies. He founded and developed a number of strategy, supply chain, optimisation and innovation companies.
These companies include Red Planet Ventures, which Flynn founded and sold to Deloitte in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://irishtechnews.ie/former-wayra-ireland-team-launch-new-business-accelerator-red-planet/|title=FORMER WAYRA IRELAND TEAM LAUNCH NEW BUSINESS ACCELERATOR – RED PLANET – Irish Tech News|website=irishtechnews.ie|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-22}}</ref>
Other companies included BeChange, Promech, Synecco, Ideaz, Global Blackswan, Boomerang Investments and Katawave: The Business Imagination Studio. Katawave works with clients to re-imagine Corporate, Business unit or Product Strategies that are not obvious, and create real long term sustainable advantage. Katawave works with clients such as Pernod Ricard, Johnson and Johnson and Pfizer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/regionals/droghedaindependent/news/mccullen-signs-up-for-katawave-35394419.html|title=Irish Independent}}</ref>
Bernard Flynn is also an early investor in Grid Finance recognising the power of the crowd.

'''Carman George Blough''' (November 11, 1895 – March 9, 1981) was an American accountant, professor of accounting, and civil servant. He is described as "one of the most influential 'high priests' of the profession in the Twentieth Century."<ref>Maurice Moonitz. "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/246745 Memorial: Carman George Blough 1895–1981]," ''The Accounting Review,'' Vol. 57, No. 1 (Jan., 1982), pp. 147–160</ref> He was inducted into the [[Accounting Hall of Fame]] in 1954.<ref>[[Thomas J. Burns]], and [[Edward N. Coffman]]. ''The Accounting Hall of Fame: profiles of thirty-six members.'' College of Administrative Science, Ohio State University, 1976.</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Johnstown, Pennsylvania]], to Silas S. and Mary Wertz Blough, Blough obtained his BA in economics in 1917 from [[Manchester College (Indiana)|Manchester College]], and his MA in 1922 from the [[University of Wisconsin-Madison|University of Wisconsin]]. In the same year he obtained his CPA certification for the state of Wisconsin. In the year 1932–33 he did graduate work at Harvard University.<ref name="AHF 2015">[http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/carman-george-blough/ Carman George Blough] in ''The Accounting Hall of Fame.'' Accessed 11.02.2015.</ref>
After his graduation in 1917 Blough started as lecturer at the [[Bridgewater College]] in 1917, spent two years at Fond du Lac, Wisconsin High School as head of the commercial department, and was instructor in accounting at the University of Wisconsin from 1920 to 1922. From 1922 to 1929 he was employed in the state of Wisconsin civil administration. In 1929 he was appointed professor at the [[University of North Dakota]] and head of its accounting department, and in 1933 he moved to the [[Armour Institute of Technology]], where he was professor and head of the social science department for another year.<ref name="AHF 2015"/>
In 1934 Blough was among the first to join the new [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]. He started as staff member, and became the first Chief Accountant of the Commission.<ref>Julia Grant. "[http://clio.lib.olemiss.edu/cdm/ref/collection/aah/id/206 Chief Accountants of the Securities and Exchange Commission]" in Michael Chatfield, [[Richard Vangermeersch]] (eds.), ''History of Accounting: An International Encyclopedia''. 1996/2014. pp. 120-122.</ref>
From 1938 to 1942 he joined [[Arthur Andersen & Co.]] as partner, but resigned when the United States entered [[World War II]], serving in several federal functions. In 1944 he became research director at the [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]], and was an adjunct professor of accounting at [[Columbia University]] from 1947 until his retirement in 1961.<ref name="AHF 2015"/>

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} [[Image:Catherine Cranston.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The resolute Kate Cranston around 1903, dressed in the [[1850s in fashion|style of the 1850s]].]] '''Catherine Cranston''' (27 May 1849 – 18 April 1934), widely known as '''Kate Cranston''' or '''Miss Cranston''', was a leading figure in the development of [[tea room]]s. She is nowadays chiefly remembered as a major patron of [[Charles Rennie Mackintosh]] and [[Margaret MacDonald (artist)|Margaret MacDonald]], in [[Glasgow]], Scotland. The name of ''Miss Cranston's Tea Rooms'' lives on in reminiscences of Glasgow in its heyday.
==Background== Her father, George Cranston, was a baker and pastry maker and, in 1849, the year of her birth, he became proprietor of the ''[[Edinburgh and Glasgow Railway]] Chop House and Commercial Lodgings'' at No. 39 George Square in Glasgow city centre.<ref name="Glasgow Story"/> The hotel was renamed the Royal Horse, then renamed again in May 1852 to become ''Cranston's Hotel and Dining Rooms'', offering: :"Convenient Coffee room and detached Smoking Rooms on Ground Floor, commodious Commercial Room and Parlour, comfortable Bed-rooms and Baths, &c. Coffee always ready. Cigars, wines, spirits, ales, Newspapers, Time-Tables, Writing Materials. ''Superior and varied Bill of Fare at the usual moderate charges.''<ref name="Glasgow Story">{{cite web | url = http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSA01336&t=2&urltp=searchq.php%3Fqsearch%3Dcranston%26amp%3Bstart%3D0%26amp%3Bend%3D20%26amp%3Bft%3D36%26amp%3Bl%3Dy | title = Advertisement, Post Office Directory 1852-3 | publisher = The Glasgow Story | accessdate = 30 April 2006}}</ref> Her slightly older brother Stuart (1848–1921) became a tea dealer and, according to ''Glasgow in 1901'', was "a pioneer of the business" there of "tea shops pure and simple" who by 1901 had three such tearooms offering nothing more substantial to eat than a sandwich. Kate went on to create much more of a social facility.<ref name=G1901>{{cite book | first= James Hamilton | last= Muir | authorlink= | author2= Muirhead Bone, James Bone and Archibald Hamilton Charteris, under the collective pen name of Muirhead Hamilton Bone | year= 1901 | title= Glasgow in 1901 | edition= facsimile reissue 2001 | publisher= William Hodge & Co. of Glasgow, reissued by White Cockade Publishing | location= Oxford | isbn=1-873487-09-6 }}</ref>
Like other cities in the United Kingdom, Glasgow was then a centre of the [[temperance movement]] which sought an alternative to male-centred [[pub]]s. Tea had previously been a luxury for the rich, but from the 1830s it was promoted as an alternative to alcoholic drinks, and many new cafés and coffee houses were opened, catering more for ordinary people. However it was not until the 1880s that tea rooms and tea shops became popular and fashionable.<ref name=Tea4you>{{cite web | url = http://www.tea.co.uk/index.php?pgId=98 | title = Tea 4 You: A Social History | publisher = UK Tea Council | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref>
==Miss Cranston's Tea Rooms== [[Image:Miss Cranston's.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Poster design by Charles Rennie Mackintosh.]] In 1878 Miss Kate Cranston opened her first tearoom, the Crown Luncheon Room, on [[Argyle Street, Glasgow]].<ref name=glasgowmuseums>{{cite web | url = http://www.glasgowmuseums.com/showProject.cfm?venueid=0&itemid=42 | title = Charles Rennie Mackintosh's Ingram Street Tearooms | publisher = Glasgow Museums – Projects | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref> She set high standards of service, food quality and cleanliness, and her innovation lay in seeing the social need for something more than a restaurant or a simple "tea shop", and in putting equal attention into providing amenities designed in the latest style. Her first tearoom was decorated in a contemporary baronial style. On 16 September 1886 she opened her Ingram Street tearoom and in 1888 commissioned [[George Henry Walton|George Walton]] to decorate a new smoking room in the [[Arts and Crafts movement|Arts and Crafts style]] in one of her tea rooms.<ref name=arts&crafts>{{cite web | url = http://www.achome.co.uk/biographies/biographies.htm | title = Arts & Crafts Home | publisher = Mark Golding – Projects | accessdate = 6 May 2006}}</ref>
In 1892 she became happily married to John Cochrane,<ref name=famousscots>{{cite web | url = http://www.rampantscotland.com/famous/blfamcranston.htm | title = Famous Scots – Kate Cranston (1850–1934) | publisher = rampantscotland | accessdate = 30 April 2006}}</ref> but continued to trade under the name of ''Miss Cranston's Tearooms''. She opened new tearooms in Buchanan Street in 1897 (designed by [[George Washington Browne]]), expanded to take over the whole building in Argyle Street by 1898 (designed by [[H and D Barclay]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=200086|title=Dictionary of Scottish Architects - DSA Architect Biography Report (August 6, 2018, 11:04 am)|first=David|last=Goold|date=|website=www.scottisharchitects.org.uk|accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref>), then completed her chain of four establishments with the [[Willow Tearooms]] (by [[Charles Rennie Mackintosh]]) in [[Sauchiehall Street]], opened in 1903.<ref name=glasgowmuseums/>
While other cities offered very expensive and very basic tea rooms by 1901, Kate Cranston set the standard in Glasgow for more welcoming establishments. Rooms were provided for ladies only and for gentlemen only, as well as luncheon rooms where they could dine together and smoking rooms and billiards rooms for the gentlemen. ''Miss Cranston's Tea Rooms'' became social centres for all, for business men and apprentices, for ladies and ladies' maids. The ''Ladies Rooms'' were a particular success, newly allowing respectable women to get out and meet together without male company. Unlike cafes or tearooms in other cities, there was no intrusive supervision and those having tea had an assortment of [[Scone (bread)|Scone]]s and cakes to hand, with a discreet notice reminding newcomers to remember the amount consumed. At "the accounting", ''Glasgow in 1901'' reported, "One states the amount of ones indebtedness, and receives a check therefor from the attendant maiden. This, with the corresponding coin or coins, one hands in at the pay-desk, and so home. Nothing could be simpler or less irritating."<ref name=G1901/><ref name=Chambers>{{cite book | first= | last= | authorlink= | year= 1991 | title= Charles Rennie Mackintosh | edition= Originally published: Richard Drew, 1987 | publisher= Chambers | location= Edinburgh | isbn=0-550-22540-4 }}</ref>
The city was a centre of artistic innovation at the time, and the tearooms served as art galleries for paintings by the "[[Glasgow School|Glasgow Boys]]". The architect Sir [[Edwin Lutyens]] visited the Buchanan Street tearoom in 1898, finding it "just a little outré", and wrote from there to his wife that "Miss Cranston is now Mrs. Cochrane, a dark, fat wee body with black sparkling luminous eyes, wears a bonnet garnished with roses, and has made a fortune by supplying cheap clean goods in surroundings prompted by the New Art Glasgow School."<ref name=Chambers/><ref name=pocketguide>{{cite book | first= John | last= McKean | authorlink= |author2=Colin Baxter | year= 1998 | title= Charles Rennie Mackintosh Pocket Guide | edition= | publisher= Colin Baxter Photography Ltd. | location= Grantown-on-Spey | isbn=1-900455-48-X }}</ref>
Tea rooms opened around the city, and in the late 1880s fine hotels elsewhere in Britain and in America began to offer tea service in tea rooms and tea courts.<ref name=classiccafes>{{cite web|url=http://www.classiccafes.co.uk/History.html |title=Classic Cafes: An Intimate History |publisher=Adrian Maddox |accessdate=5 May 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160323201633/http://www.classiccafes.co.uk/History.html |archivedate=23 March 2016 |df=dmy }}</ref> ''Glasgow in 1901'' reported that "Glasgow, in truth, is a very [[Tokyo|Tokio]] for tea-rooms. Nowhere can one have so much for so little, and nowhere are such places more popular and frequented." and that "It is not the accent of the people, nor the painted houses, nor yet the absence of [[Scottish Highlands|Highland]] policemen that makes the Glasgow man in London feel that he is in a foreign town and far from home. It is a simpler matter. It is the lack of tea-shops."<ref name=G1901/> The original Sauchiehall Street tearoom building is presently being restored and is scheduled for reopening in 2018. It is planned to develop the adjacent building as a Mackintosh visitor centre. The 'Willow Tearooms' brand has been separated from the building and is now run privately at a location within a department store further along the street and at Buchanan Street adjacent to Miss Cranston's original premises. Both locations feature recreated Mackintosh furniture and interior features.
===Walton and Mackintosh=== [[Image:Mackintosh, BuchananTearooms Frieze.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Mackintosh's design for the frieze at the Buchanan Street tearoom.]] [[George Henry Walton|George Walton]] set up ''George Walton & Co, Ecclesiastical and House Decorators'' on the basis of his 1888 commission from Kate Cranston, and in 1896 was commissioned by her to design the interiors of new tearooms, designed and built by [[George Washington Browne]] of [[Edinburgh]], at 91–93 [[Buchanan Street]], which opened the following year.<ref name=arts&crafts/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSE01207&t=2&urltp=searchq.php%3Fqsearch%3Dcranston%26amp%3Bstart%3D0%26amp%3Bend%3D20%26amp%3Bft%3D36%26amp%3Bl%3Dy | title = Coat tree by George Walton | publisher = The Glasgow Story | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref> He was assisted in this by [[Charles Rennie Mackintosh]] who designed wall [[mural]]s in the form of [[stencil]]led [[frieze]]s depicting opposing pairs of elongated female figures surrounded by roses for the ladies' tearoom, the luncheon room and the smokers' gallery.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.designmuseum.org/design/index.php?id=114 | title = Charles Rennie Mackintosh...Designer Information | publisher = The Design Museum | accessdate = 6 May 2006 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060427233547/http://www.designmuseum.org/design/index.php?id=114 | archivedate = 27 April 2006 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> :"It is believed (and averred) that in no other town can you see in a place of refreshment such ingenious and beautiful decorations in the style of the new art as in Miss Cranston's shop in Buchanan Street. Indeed, so general in the city is this belief that it has caused the Glasgow man of the better sort to coin a new adjective denoting the height of beauty... 'It's quite Kate Cranston-ish !' "<ref name= G1901/>
Kate Cranston expanded her first tearoom to take over the whole building at 114 Argyle Street and commissioned Walton to design a new more modern interior, which opened in 1898. Walton's work included fireplaces, stencilled wall murals and stained glass panels for the doors. In the luncheon room the murals and door panels had a rose pattern theme. The furniture was designed by Mackintosh, introducing for the first time his characteristic high-backed chairs.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSE01206&t=2&urltp=searchq.php%3Fqsearch%3Dcranston%26amp%3Bstart%3D0%26amp%3Bend%3D20%26amp%3Bft%3D36%26amp%3Bl%3Dy | title = Glass panel by George Walton | publisher = The Glasgow Story | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref>
In 1900 Kate Cranston gave Mackintosh the opportunity to redesign an entire room, at the Ingram Street tearoom. He had just recently married the artist [[Margaret MacDonald (artist)|Margaret MacDonald]], and together they created the White Dining Room, including a hallway opening onto the street and divided off by a wooden screen with [[Stained glass|leaded glass]] panels, giving those entering glimpses into the room itself. His fame was spreading, and in 1902 ''[[The Studio (magazine)|The Studio]]'' wrote of "Miss Cranston, whose tea-rooms, designed by Mr. Mackintosh, are reckoned by some of the pilgrims to Glasgow as one of the sights of the city."<ref name=glasgowmuseums/><ref name=Chambers/><ref name=willowtearooms>{{cite web | url = http://www.willowtearooms.co.uk/mackintosh.htm | title = Mackintosh % Kate Cranston | publisher = The Willow Tearooms | accessdate = 5 May 2006 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060414201559/http://www.willowtearooms.co.uk/mackintosh.htm | archivedate = 14 April 2006 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
===The Willow Tearooms=== {{main|Willow Tearooms}} [[Image:Room de Luxe waitresses.jpg|thumb|left|Miss Cranston's waitresses, seen in the Room de Luxe of the Willow Tea Rooms.]] Next Kate Cranston gave Mackintosh the major commission for an entire building in Sauchiehall Street, again in collaboration with his wife Margaret MacDonald on designs for the interiors. Behind a strikingly simple new façade this building provided three interlinked main tearooms at the ground floor and on a first floor gallery, with steps from that leading up a further half-storey to the famous "Room de Luxe" stretching the width of the building above the main entrance and front tearoom.
In a humorous review of the new tearoom for the [[Glasgow Evening News|Glasgow ''Evening News'']] titled ''Erchie in an Art Tea Room'', [[Neil Munro (Hugh Foulis)|Neil Munro]] described the "Room de Looks": ::::::"The chairs is no like ony ither chairs ever I clapped eyes on, but ye could easy guess they were chairs, and a' roond the place there's a lump o' looking-gless wi' purple leeks pented on it every noo and then."<ref name=Chambers/>
In 1905 ''[[Dekorative Kunst]]'' featured a special issue about the Willow Tea Rooms written by [[Hermann Muthesius]] who advised that "Today any visitor to Glasgow can rest body and soul in Miss Cranston's Tea Rooms and for a few pence drink tea, have breakfast and dream that he is in fairy land."<ref name=Chambers/>
===Further projects=== [[Image:Cranston's exhibition cafe.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Menu design by [[Margaret MacDonald (artist)|Margaret MacDonald Mackintosh]].]] Although the Willow Tearooms completed her chain, and remains the most famous of her tea rooms, Kate Cranston carried out several more projects, and Mackintosh provided increasingly innovative designs. In 1904 she commissioned him to carry out the redecoration and design of new furniture for the mansion of ''Hous'hill'' in [[Nitshill]] which was home to herself and her husband John Cochrane.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSB00285&t=2&urltp=searchq.php%3Fqsearch%3Dcranston%26amp%3Bstart%3D0%26amp%3Bend%3D20%26amp%3Bft%3D36%26amp%3Bl%3Dy | title = Househill (Hous'hill) | publisher = The Glasgow Story | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSE01088&t=2&urltp=searchq.php%3Fqsearch%3Dcranston%26amp%3Bstart%3D0%26amp%3Bend%3D20%26amp%3Bft%3D36%26amp%3Bl%3Dy | title = Furniture from Hous'hill | publisher = The Glasgow Story | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref>
Mackintosh carried out further work on the Argyle Street tearoom in 1906 to design a basement conversion to form ''The Dutch kitchen''. He did further redesigns for rooms in the Ingram Street tearooms, creating the ''Cloister Room'' and the ''Chinese Room'' in 1911. The latter provides an exotic fantasy, with bright blue finished timber screens incorporating a cashier's kiosk, elaborate door lintels and dark blue finished furniture, all in Mackintosh's version of an oriental style.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}}
In the same year Kate Cranston provided temporary "Exhibition Cafes" at the ''Scottish International Exhibition'', apparently set up and designed by Charles Rennie Mackintosh, though nothing is now known of his scheme for this. The menu card designed by [[Margaret MacDonald (artist)|Margaret MacDonald Mackintosh]] shows the name for the tearooms, ''[[Cockade|The White Cockade]]'', but makes no visual connection with this reference to [[Jacobitism]]. It gives credit for supply of cakes to Miss Cranstons Bakery, 292 St Vincent St., Glasgow.<ref name=Chambers/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSA05208 | title = Kate Cranston | publisher = The Glasgow Story | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | first= Nathaniel | last= Harris | authorlink= | year= 1996 | title= The Life and Works of Rennie Mackintosh | edition= | publisher= Parragon Book Service Ltd. | location= Avonmouth | isbn=0-7525-1445-8 }}</ref>
[[Image:Mackintosh, Willow Tearooms Interior Study, 1917.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Design for ''The Dug Out''.]] In 1916 Kate opened ''Cranston's Cinema De Luxe'' in an entertainment complex designed for her by the architect [[James Miller (architect)|James Miller]], occupying the third floor of a six-storey building in Renfield Street, Glasgow.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.theglasgowstory.com/image.php?inum=TGSA00322 | title = Classic Cinema | publisher = The Glasgow Story | accessdate = 5 May 2006}}</ref>
In 1917 Mackintosh carried out his last commission for Kate Cranston, and indeed one of his last architectural works to be constructed, with the design of an extension of the Willow Tea Rooms into the basement of the building next door to create ''The Dug Out'' in a style that anticipated [[Art Deco]].<ref name=Chambers/><ref name=pocketguide/>
Kate Cranston was greatly distressed when her husband died in 1917. She sold off her tea rooms and other businesses, and withdrew from public life. She had no children, and when she died in 1934 her will left two-thirds of her estate to the poor of Glasgow.<ref name=famousscots/>
==Legacy== [[Image:Room de Luxe2.jpg|thumb|right|150px|The Room de Luxe of the Willow Tearooms today.]] Even though Kate Cranston had sold her tea rooms off, the name ''Miss Cranston's Tea Rooms'' long remained a byword for quality and for memories of Glasgow's heyday at the turn of the century. By 1938 tea rooms at 43 Argyll Arcade, 28 Buchanan Street, Renfield Street and Queen Street were being run by ''Cranston's Tea Rooms Ltd.'' They went into liquidation in 1954 and their premises were sold on for other uses.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/cranston.html | title = Records of Cranston's Tea Rooms Ltd, Glasgow, Scotland | publisher = Archives Hub | accessdate = 5 May 2006 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120723010038/http://www.archiveshub.ac.uk/news/cranston.html | archivedate = 23 July 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
The Willow Tearooms were renamed, then in 1928 they were sold on to Daly's department store who incorporated the premises into their shop, keeping the Room de Luxe in operation as the department store tea room.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}}
''Miss Cranston's Tearooms'' on Ingram Street continued in use as catering facilities from 1930 for ''Cooper's & Co.'', then in 1950 the rooms came into the ownership of Glasgow City Council and were used for storage and a souvenir shop. In 1971 the furnishings were removed into storage when the building was demolished, and they are now the only original set of Mackintosh tearoom interiors to survive. Ownership was transferred to Glasgow Museums in 1978, and after a further period of storage restoration work began in 1993. The ''Ladies' Luncheon Room'' was exhibited three years later, and the ''Chinese Room'' and ''Cloister Room'' have since been restored. The Glasgow Museums website reports that they are "currently assessing what will be needed to research and preserve the Charles Rennie Mackintosh interiors of the Ingram Street Tearooms for future public display."<ref name=glasgowmuseums/> and prospective plans now exist to install at least some of the interiors at the new V&A museum in Dundee.
[[Image:The Willow Tearooms Glasgow.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The restored Willow Tearooms building.]] While Mackintosh's reputation was eclipsed by the 1920s, he was later recognised as a pioneer of [[modern architecture]], particularly in terms of the exterior of the Willow Tea Rooms. In the 1960s a resurgence of interest in [[Art Nouveau]] brought him international fame, and the furniture and designs he and his wife created for Kate Cranston are now extremely valuable.{{Citation needed|date=November 2007}}
When Daly's closed, the Willow Tea Rooms were restored to an approximation of their original appearance. Catering reopened in the Room de Luxe, later extending to the recreated Tea Gallery, and was so successful that the business opened a new tearoom on the first floor of a building in Buchanan Street, near the original Buchanan Street and Ingram Street tearooms, fitted out with replicas of the White Dining Room and the Chinese Room from the Ingram Street tearoom. Confusingly, it trades under the name of ''The Willow Tea Rooms'', as this now appears to be more familiar to visitors than Miss Cranston's name.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.willowtearooms.co.uk/buchanan.htm | title = The Willow in Buchanan Street | publisher = The Willow Tearooms | accessdate = 5 May 2006 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060414201720/http://www.willowtearooms.co.uk/buchanan.htm | archivedate = 14 April 2006 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> {{Commons category|Willow Tearooms}} However, these new tearooms draw renewed attention to the contribution Kate's patronage made to Mackintosh's work, and the impact she had on the social life of Glasgow is still remembered in popular books such as ''Tea at Miss Cranston's''.<ref>{{cite book | first= Anna | last= Blair | authorlink= | year= 1985 | title= Tea at Miss Cranston's | edition= | publisher= Shepheard-Walwyn | location= London | isbn=0-85683-081-X }}</ref>
The continuing interest in Miss Cranston is also reflected in the prices realised for items associated with her tearooms; for example ₤940 for six pieces of cutlery stamped Miss Cranston's.<ref>{{cite web|title=SIX PIECES OF CUTLERY designed by Charles Rennie Mackintosh for Miss Cranston's Tearooms, circa 1905|url=http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/LotDetailsPrintable.aspx?intObjectID=3908334|website=www.christies.com|publisher=Chirisite's|accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref>
In October 2018, it was announced that Cranston would feature on a design for [[The Royal Bank of Scotland £20 note]] to be circulated in 2020, the first woman other than [[Queen Elizabeth II]] to be depicted on a [[Banknotes of Scotland|banknote of that denomination in that country]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eveningtimes.co.uk/news/17001564.glasgow-pioneer-kate-cranston-honoured-on-new-20-note/|title=Glasgow pioneer Kate Cranston honoured on new £20 note|work=[[Evening Times]]|author=Caroline Wilson|date=23 October 2018|accessdate=23 October 2018}}</ref> (images of [[Nan Shepherd]] had been on a £5, [[Mary Somerville]] and [[Mary Slessor]] on a £10 and [[Elsie Inglis]] on a £50 in the past,<ref name="Scotsman2">{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/new-rbs-bank-notes-to-feature-nan-shepherd-and-mary-somerville-1-4108245|title=New RBS bank notes to feature Nan Shepherd and Mary Somerville|date=25 April 2016|work=[[The Scotsman]]|accessdate=23 October 2018}}</ref> while notes issued by English banks had already featured [[Elizabeth Fry]], [[Florence Nightingale]] and [[Jane Austen]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/bbc-journalist-mocked-for-saying-jane-austen-first-woman-on-bank-notes-a3634951.html|title='What about the Queen?': BBC journalist mocked for saying Jane Austen is first woman on bank notes |work=[[Evening Standard]]|author=Harriet Pavey|date=14 September 2017 |accessdate=23 October 2018}}</ref>

Consulting|LEK Partnership]]}} | spouse = Deborah}} '''Sir Damon Marcus Buffini''' (born 1962)<ref name=birth/> is a British businessman and governor of the [[Wellcome Trust]].<ref name=wellcome/> He was formerly head of the [[private equity]] company [[Permira]].<ref name=permira>{{cite web|title= Profile of Buffini at Permira|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709033543/http://www.permira.com/permira/en/peopledetail.jsp?id=2089|archivedate=9 July 2007|url=http://www.permira.com/permira/en/peopledetail.jsp?id=2089|publisher=permira.com}}</ref><ref>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/article542274.ece The Times Newspaper article on Damon Buffini]</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Tom Rawstone|year=2007|title=King of the private equity bounty hunters – but how did he do it?|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150711204241/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-466262/King-private-equity-bounty-hunters--did-it.html|archivedate=11 July 2015|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-466262/King-private-equity-bounty-hunters--did-it.html|work=[[Daily Mail]]|location=London}}</ref>
==Education and early life== Born in [[Leicester]] in 1962,<ref name=birth/> the son of an African-American serviceman and a British woman, he was educated in Leicester and graduated with a degree in Law from [[St John's College, Cambridge]], and has an [[MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School]].<ref name=permira/>
==Career== Out of a list of 100, Buffini topped the list as the most powerful black male in the Britain by ''[[New Nation]]''. He also ranked number three by the Times Power 100 for people who hold sway over British Business.<ref>[http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/movers_and_shakers/article3142396.ece Inventive and dynamic risk-takers who changed the face of Britain – Times Online<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{subscription required}}</ref> Boasting power and influence, together with a personal fortune of between £100m and £200m., Buffini was appointed to then Prime Minister Gordon Brown's business advisory panel.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/race/story/0,,2156616,00.html The real black power list of 100 leading role models | Media | The Observer]</ref>
Buffini worked for [[L.E.K Consulting]], and under the firm's scholarship scheme undertook an MBA from Harvard Business School.<ref name=permira /> On return to the UK he joined Imperial Group working as a management consultant, before being recruited by [[Jon Moulton]] (now{{when|date=June 2016}} head of rival firm [[Better Capital]]), in 1988 to join [[Schroders]] [[leveraged buyout]] team, known then as Schroder Ventures Europe.<ref name=guardian>[https://www.theguardian.com/executivepay/story/0,1204,1344902,00.html Permira boss takes home £3.2m – and no surprise as spotlight falls on Buffini | Business | The Guardian]</ref>
Buffini became a partner in 1992, and promoted to Managing Partner of the UK business in 1999, and Managing Partner in 2000, just before he led a [[management buyout]] group and renamed the firm Permira.<ref name=permira/> Buffini took home £3.2 million plus bonuses in 2004.<ref name=permira />
Buffini was also a non-executive board member of [[SVG Capital]] plc<ref name=birth/> and chairman and co-founder of the [[Social Business Trust]].
He is also a main board member of the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] and a trustee of the [[Royal Anniversary Trust]], which administers The Queen's Anniversary Prizes for Higher and Further Education.{{when|date=June 2016}}
In September 2012 Buffini was appointed to the Board of Governors at [[The Wellcome Trust]].<ref name=wellcome>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160622102531/https://wellcome.ac.uk/about-us/governance/board-governors|archivedate=22 June 2016|url=https://wellcome.ac.uk/about-us/governance/board-governors|website=wellcome.ac.uk|publisher=[[Wellcome Trust]]|location=London|title=Board of Governors|author=Anon|year=2016}}</ref>
==Awards and honours== Buffini was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the 2016 Birthday Honours for voluntary and charitable services.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=61608|supp=y|page=B2|date=11 June 2016}}</ref>
==Personal life== Married to a solicitor Deborah, the couple have three children and a family home in [[Weybridge]]<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/men/article1434499.ece Invisible man forced into view by his golden touch – ''Times Online''<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{subscription required}}</ref> and a city flat in [[Wandsworth]]. Buffini plays [[tennis]] and [[golf]], [[Association football|football]] for a local amateur side, and supports [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Profile: Damon Buffini, The football fan who calls the shots|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160318050335/http://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/feb/20/politics.tradeunions1|archivedate=18 March 2016|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/feb/20/politics.tradeunions1|website=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|author=Jill Treanor|year=2007}}</ref>

[[Brussels]] B-1000 |editor = [[Stephanie De Smedt]] |sister newspapers = L'Echo |website = [http://www.tijd.be www.tijd.be] }} '''''De Tijd''''' ({{IPA-nl|də ˈtɛit|lang}}, ''The Times'') is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[newspaper]] that mainly focuses on business and economics. It is printed on salmon pink paper since May 2009, following the example of its colleagues ''[[Financial Times]]'', ''[[Het Financieele Dagblad]]'', ''[[Financial Times Deutschland|FT Deutschland]]'' and many more. ==History and profile== Established under the name of '''''De Financieel-Economische Tijd''''' (''"The Financial Economical Times"'') in 1968,{{cite web|title=Belgium Titles |url=http://www.business-press.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=66&Itemid=13 |work=Business Press |accessdate=4 December 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141226003329/http://www.business-press.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=66&Itemid=13 |archivedate=26 December 2014 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|title=European News Resources|url=http://guides.nyu.edu/content.php?pid=74313&sid=704214|work=NYU Libraries|accessdate=24 January 2015}} in 2003 the paper was renamed as ''De Tijd''.{{cite journal|author=Pieter Maeseele|title=On news media and democratic debate: Framing agricultural biotechnology in Northern Belgium|journal=The International Communication Gazette|date=2011|volume=73|issue=1-2|url=http://gaz.sagepub.com/content/73/1-2/83.full.pdf+html|accessdate=30 January 2015}} ''De Tijd'' is owned by De Persgroep (50%) and Rossel (50%). The current [[editor-in-chief]] of ''De Tijd'' is Stephanie De Smedt. It is published in [[Dutch language]]. ''De Tijd'' is a typical financial daily, covering economy and business, financial markets and national and international politics. The paper is the main information source for Belgian managers (CIM-survey 2009). It is published from Tuesday to Saturday with no Sunday or Monday edition. The weekend edition is enriched with two magazines: Netto, on personal finance, and Sabato on lifestyle. In March 2012 the paper began to be published in [[Berliner format]].{{cite news|title=New sizes for L'Echo and De Tijd|url=http://www.adnative.net/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=76186&title=belgium-new-sizes-for-lecho-and-de-tijd#.VNPc02SsXRB|accessdate=5 February 2015|work=Adnative|date=29 March 2012}} ''De Tijd'' was named as the [[European Newspaper Award|Newspaper of the Year]] in the category of nationwide newspaper by the European Newspapers Congress in 2012.{{cite web|title=14th European Newspaper Award|url=http://www.editorial-design.com/13/e/Press_Release_14th_ENA.pdf|work=Editorial Design|accessdate=4 December 2014|format=Press Release|year=2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313051352/http://www.editorial-design.com/13/e/Press_Release_14th_ENA.pdf|archivedate=13 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} == Mediafin == ''De Tijd'' was established and financially supported by the [[Vlaams Economisch Verbond]]. In 2005, two major Belgian media conglomerates, the [[Flanders|Flemish]] [[De Persgroep]] which is the owner of ''[[Het Laatste Nieuws]]'' and ''[[De Morgen]]'' among others and the [[Walloon Region|Walloon]] [[Rossel (Belgium)|Rossel]] which is the owner of ''[[Le Soir]]'' among others purchased [[Uitgeversbedrijf Tijd]], the mother company of ''De Tijd'' and Editeco, the publishing company of ''[[L'Echo]]'', the [[French (language)|French]] counterpart. Both newspapers were integrated in the newly established [[Mediafin]], in which De Persgroep and Rossel each hold a stake of 50 percent.{{cite journal|author=Koen Panis et. al.|title=Does Media Cross-Ownership Translate into Cross-Promotion?|journal=Journalism Studies|date=2014|doi=10.1080/1461670X.2014.953780|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/1461670X.2014.953780|accessdate=12 December 2014}} Both newspapers stayed independent, but they work in the same building at the historical site of [[Tour & Taxis]] in [[Brussels]] since the merger. Frederik Delaplace is editorial director of [[Mediafin]]. ==Circulation== The circulation of ''De Tijd'' was 59,144 copies and its market share was 4.7% in 2002.{{cite web|author=David Ward|title=A Mapping Study of Media Concentration and Ownership in Ten European Countries|url=http://77.87.161.246/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/A-Mapping-Study-of-Media-Concentration-and-Ownership-in-Ten-European-Countries.pdf|work=Dutch Media Authority|accessdate=12 August 2014|year=2004}} The circulation of the paper was 39,315 copies in 2008 and 36,569 copies in 2009.{{cite web|title=National newspapers total circulation|url=http://www.ifabc.org/site/assets/media/National-Newspapers_total-circulation_IFABC_09-07-12.xls|work=International Federation of Audit Bureaux of Circulations|accessdate=3 December 2014}} It was 37,448 copies in 2010, 39,431 copies in 2011 and a total circulation of 41.065 (digital+print) in 2015. According to the {{Interlanguage link multi|Centrum voor Informatie over de Media|nl}}, (CIM)[http://www.cim.be cim.be] {{nl icon}}, {{fr icon}} ''De Tijd'' had a total paid for distribution of 37,031 copies at the end of 2011. It reached 123.300 readers every day. ''De Tijd'' had an average market share of 6,4% in [[Flanders]]. The newspaper has been investing in multimedia projects since 2007. The website of '''De Tijd''' now reaches about 150.000 unique visitors a day. The website has a (frequency based) paid for model since May 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.mediafin.be/nl/content/lezersmarkt|title=Lezersmarkt - mediafin|work=mediafin.be}} The newspaper is also available via mobile, it has [[Mobile app|app]]s for both [[iPad]] and [[iPhone]] and a html-based app for other tablets. == Slogans == * ''Het Lijfblad van de Manager'' (1968–1996). * ''Voor kennis van Zaken'' (1996–2002). * ''Uit op Inzicht'' (2002–2003). * ''De Essentie'' (2003–2006). * ''Voor kennis van Zaken'' (2006–2007). * ''Tel mee'' (2008-2010) * ''Voor belangrijke zaken neemt u De Tijd'' (since 2010) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.tijd.be Official website] * [http://www.krantenindeklas.be/index.php?id=30 Newspapers in the class room] {{nl icon}} * [http://netto.tijd.be ''Netto'' magazine] * [http://belegger.tijd.be ''Belegger'' magazine] * [http://sabato.tijd.be ''Sabato'' magazine] {{Belgian newspapers}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tijd}} [[Category:1968 establishments in Belgium]] [[Category:Business newspapers]] [[Category:Dutch-language newspapers published in Belgium]] [[Category:Media in Brussels]] [[Category:Publications established in 1968]]

{{About|American law in criminal defense|other uses of "Duress"|Duress (disambiguation)}} {{Criminal defenses}} In [[jurisprudence]], '''duress''' or '''coercion''' refers to a situation whereby a person performs an act as a result of violence, threat, or other pressure against the person. ''[[Black's Law Dictionary]]'' (6th ed.) defines duress as "any unlawful [[intimidation|threat]] or [[coercion]] used... to induce another to act [or not act] in a manner [they] otherwise would not [or would]". Duress is pressure exerted upon a person to coerce that person to perform an act they ordinarily would not perform. The notion of duress must be distinguished both from [[undue influence]] in the [[civil law (common law)|civil law]]. In [[criminal law]], [[duress and necessity]] are different defenses.<ref>''[[People v. Unger]]'', 362 N.E.2d 319 (1977)</ref><ref>Handbook on Criminal Law 381 (1972)</ref>
Duress has two aspects. One is that it negates the person's [[consent]] to an act, such as [[Human sexual activity|sexual activity]] or the entering into a contract; or, secondly, as a possible [[defense (legal)|legal defense]] or justification to an otherwise unlawful act.<ref name=Gaines>{{cite book |last=Gaines |first=Larry |authorlink= |author2=Miller, LeRoy |title=Criminal Justice In Action: The Core |year=2006 |publisher=[[Thomson/Wadsworth]] |location= |isbn=0-495-00305-0 }}</ref> A defendant utilizing the duress defense admits to breaking the law, but claims that he/she is not [[Legal liability|liable]] because, even though the act broke the [[law]], it was only performed because of extreme unlawful pressure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pi1stclass.com/glossary.htm|title=1st Class Investigations Glossary|publisher=}}</ref> In criminal law, a duress defense is similar to a plea of guilty, admitting partial [[culpability]], so that if the defense is not accepted then the criminal act is admitted.
Duress or [[coercion]] can also be raised in an allegation of [[rape]] or other [[sexual assault]] to negate a defense of consent on the part of the person making the allegation.
==Discussion== A defendant who raises a defense of duress has actually done everything to constitute the ''[[actus reus]]'' of the crime, and has the ''[[mens rea]]'' because they intended to do it to avoid some threatened or actual harm. Thus, some degree of [[culpability]] already attaches to the defendant for what was done.
In criminal law, the defendant's motive for breaking the law is generally irrelevant unless a defendant is raising an [[affirmative defense]] allowed for by law. (Duress may or may not be allowed as an affirmative defence for some particular charge -- in particular, it is generally forbidden for [[murder]], and many jurisdictions also forbid it for [[sexual assault]]. ''[[Malum in se]]'' offences, generally, are less likely to recognise duress as a defence than ''[[malum prohibitum]]'' offences.)
A successful affirmative defence means not that a criminal act was justified, but that the act was not criminal at all. But if no affirmative defence of duress is available, then the duress may be considered as justifying a lighter [[sentence (law)|sentence]], typically in proportion to the degree of duress. If the duress is extreme enough, for example, the defendant might be found guilty of murder but given a minimal, or even trivial, sentence.
In some rare cases, a successful argument of duress -- even when not an affirmative defence -- might result in the jury [[Jury nullification|nullifying]] the charge by refusing to convict.
The basis of the defense is that the duress actually overwhelmed the defendant's will and would also have overwhelmed the will of a person of ordinary courage (a hybrid test requiring both subjective evidence of the accused's state of mind, and an objective confirmation that the failure to resist the threats was reasonable), thus rendering the entire behavior involuntary. Thus, the liability should be reduced or discharged, making the defense one of [[exculpation]].
The extent to which this defense should be allowed, if at all, is a matter of [[public policy]]. A state may say that no threat should force a person to deliberately break the law, particularly if this breach will cause significant loss or damage to a third person.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} Alternatively, a state may take the view that even though people may have ordinary levels of courage, they may nevertheless be coerced into agreeing to break the law and this human weakness should have some recognition in the law.
A mutant of duress involves [[hostage]] taking, where a person is forced to commit a criminal act under the threat, say, that their family member or close associate will be immediately killed should they refuse (commonly known as a [[Tiger kidnapping]]). This has been raised in some cases of [[ransom]], where a person commits theft or embezzlement under orders from a kidnapper in order to secure a family member's life and freedom. However, duress is not a complete defense to all crimes. For example, the general rule, both at common law and today, is that duress is never a defense to murder; that is, one is never justified in killing another innocent person even if one's own life has been threatened, although this part may be questioned when multiple people are threatened with death if the defendant does not kill a single or fewer people than threatened (such a situation is similar to the [[trolley problem]]).<ref>''People v. Anderson'', 8 Cal. 4th 767, 50 P.3d 368, 122 Cal. Rptr. 2d 587 (2002).</ref>
==Requirements== For duress to qualify as a defense, four requirements must be met:<ref name=Gaines /> # The threat must be of serious bodily harm or death # The threatened harm must be greater than the harm caused by the crime # The threat must be immediate and inescapable # The defendant must have become involved in the situation through no fault of his own
A person may also raise a duress defense when force or violence is used to compel him to enter into a contract, or to discharge.
== In contract law == {{Contract law}} ''Duress'' in the context of contract law is a [[common law]] defence brought about when one of the parties to the contract enjoyed an ascendant position in relation to the other party and abused that position by subjecting the other to ''threats.'' A party who has entered into a contract under duress is entitled to rescind or set aside the contract, rendering it voidable (in equity).
Duress is a threat of harm made to compel someone to do something against their will or judgment; especially a wrongful threat made by one person to compel a manifestation of seeming assent by another person to a transaction without real volition. - Black's Law Dictionary (8th ed. 2004)
Duress in contract law falls into two broad categories:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.4lawnotes.com/outlines/duress.htm|title=Duress : Introduction to Contracts Law|publisher=}}</ref> * Physical duress * Economic duress<ref> See ''Pao On v Lau Yiu Long'' [1979] 3 All ER 65; [[Pao On v Lau Yiu Long]]; Applied in ''Con Ange v Calogo Bloodstock AG t/as Coolmore Australia'' [2012] NSWSC 666. </ref>
===Physical duress=== ====Duress to the person==== Professor Ronald Griffin, Florida Agricultural & Mechanical College of Law, Orlando, FL, puts physical duress simply: "Your money or your life." In ''[[Barton v Armstrong]]'',<ref>''[[Barton v Armstrong]]'' [1976] AC 104 [http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKPC/1973/2.html BAILII]</ref> a decision of the [[Privy Council]], Armstrong (defendant) sought to coerce Barton (plaintiff) into executing a deed relating to the sale of certain companies by threatening to have him murdered. While the plaintiff took the threats seriously, other business reasons existed for signing the contract. An innocent party wishing to set aside a contract for duress to the person need only prove that the threat was made and that it was a reason for entry into the contract. Furthermore, once it is established that the threat was made, the onus lies on the person who made the threat to prove that the threat made no contribution to the plaintiff's decision to enter the agreement.<ref>See ''Crescendo Management Pty Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp'' (1988) 19 NSWLR 40, 46.</ref>
Common law took a narrow view of the concept of duress in that it was concerned with actual or threatened violence to the person or unlawful imprisonment. Equity, however, adopted a broader "fusion" view of what sort of pressure could constitute coercion for purposes of relief and has since prevailed. <ref>See J Paterson, A Robertson and A Duke, ''Principles of Contract Law'', (4th edn Thomson Reuters 2012)</ref>
====Duress to goods==== In such cases, one party refuses to release the goods belonging to the other party until the other party enters into a contract with them. For example, in ''Hawker Pacific Pty Ltd v Helicopter Charter Pty Ltd'' (1991) 22 NSWLR 298, the contract was set aside after Hawker Pacific's threats to withhold the helicopter from the plaintiff unless further payments were made for repairing a botched paint job.
===The elements of economic duress===
Economic duress is the use of unlawful economic pressure to compel a party to a contract to agree to demands which they would not have otherwise.<ref>{{cite web|title=Universe Tankships Inc of Monrovia v International Transport Workers Federation (The Universe Sentinel) [1981] UKHL 9|url=http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/1981/9.html|website=Bailii|accessdate= 9 August 2015}}</ref> #'''Wrongful or improper threat''': No precise definition of what is wrongful or improper. Examples include: morally wrong, criminal, or tortious conduct; one that is a threat to breach a contract "in bad faith" or threaten to withhold an admitted debt "in bad faith". #'''No reasonable alternative (but to accept the other party's terms)'''. If there is an available legal remedy, an available market substitute (in the form of funds, goods, or services), or any other sources of funds this element is not met. #'''The threat actually induces the making of the contract'''. This is a subjective standard, and takes into account the victim's age, their background (especially their education), relationship of the parties, and the ability to receive advice. #'''The other party caused the financial distress'''. The majority opinion is that the other party must have caused the distress, while the minority opinion allows them to merely take advantage of the distress.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} See ''Universe Tankships Inc of Monrovia v International Transport Workers Federation (The Universe Sentinel)'' [1981] UKHL 9<ref>{{cite web|title=Universe Tankships Inc of Monrovia v International Transport Workers Federation (The Universe Sentinel) [1981] UKHL 9|url=http://www.bailii.org/uk/cases/UKHL/1981/9.html|website=Bailii|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
==Insane duress== In criminal law, when a person is found legally insane because they believed God ordered them to do the crime ("[[deific-decree]]"), one interpretation of the insanity is that they acted under a delusion of duress by God.<ref name=CL>''Criminal Law - Cases and Materials'', 7th ed. 2012, [[Wolters Kluwer Law & Business]]; [[John Kaplan (law professor)|John Kaplan]], [[Robert Weisberg]], [[Guyora Binder]], {{ISBN|978-1-4548-0698-1}}, [https://law.stanford.edu/publications/criminal-law-cases-and-materials-7th-edition/]</ref>{{rp|615-625}}
