page.title: Effects of the 2008–10 automotive industry crisis on Canada

revision.text:
{{main|Automotive industry crisis of 2008–2010}}
The Canadian auto industry is closely linked to the U.S., due to the [[Automotive Products Trade Agreement]] and later the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA), and is in similar trouble. Canada's 3,500 car dealers, which employ 140,000 people, told the federal and Ontario governments in mid-November they are at risk from the financial crisis; they are asking the national government to help out despite a record year{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} of sales. Ottawa is considering providing financial aid to the Canadian subsidiaries of the Big Three, and possibly auto parts companies as well. The auto industry argued that loan guarantees and other help would try to save tens of thousands of Canadian jobs threatened by the sudden drop in North American car sales. Chrysler Canada has asked for $1 billion in aid, making it the only Canadian arm of the Big Three to make a specific dollar request.
Industry analyst Anthony Faria criticized the labor contracts that [[Canadian Auto Workers]] then-president [[Buzz Hargrove]] negotiated with the [[Big Three automobile manufacturers|Big Three US automobile manufacturers]] in 2007, predicting that the [[subprime mortgage crisis]] and currency would hit Canadian auto production especially hard. Faria noted that [[UAW]] president [[Ron Gettelfinger]] agreed to have the UAW's "all-in" wage, benefit and pension costs drop from a high of $75.86 per hour in 2007 to an average of about $51 per hour starting in 2010. By comparison, the CAW's cost per hour was $77 in 2007 and will rise to over $80 per hour by the end of the new contract. Faria said that Gettelfinger went into negotiations "with the right intention...Save jobs. The CAW strategy was to squeeze every dime out of them."<ref>{{cite web |first=Chris Vander |last=Doelen |url=http://www.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=63a938bc-58fa-4795-9ec4-10741d105193 |title=Thousands of CAW auto job losses predicted |work=The Windsor Star |date=2008-01-30 |accessdate=2009-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215053440/http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=63a938bc-58fa-4795-9ec4-10741d105193 |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}</ref> Hargrove was said to have "instilled backbone and an attitude that the union could always make the auto makers buckle at the bargaining table".<ref name="business.theglobeandmail.com">{{cite web|author=Derek Decloet |url=http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090309.wdecloet0310/BNStory/robColumnsBlogs/home |title=reportonbusiness.com: Columns and Blogs |publisher=Business.theglobeandmail.com |date= |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313035141/http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090309.wdecloet0310/BNStory/robColumnsBlogs/home |archivedate=2009-03-13 |df= }}</ref>
Current union president [[Ken Lewenza, Sr.|Ken Lewenza]] has argued that labor is not responsible for the bankruptcy crisis facing the Big Three automakers, saying that his members would not make concessions part of any taxpayer-funded bailout. "We don't see this as us being the problem", Lewenza said, adding he would "absolutely not" accept any further cuts after losing tens of thousands of jobs in recent years. "We've suffered our share of pain."<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5grcl5q0uPoqkOoWENxe22Q3dbqwg]{{dead link|date=January 2009}}</ref> Lawenza argued that the CAW agreed in 2007 to make concessions that will save the Big Three $900 million over three years.<ref>"Car dealers plead for government help," [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081121.wcdeals1121/BNStory/National/home ''The Canadian Press'' Nov. 21, 2008 online]; "Labour rates not a problem in auto industry: Lewenza," [http://www.edmontonsun.com/Business/News/2008/11/20/7474801.html Canadian Press, Nov. 20, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081123013323/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081121.wcdeals1121/BNStory/National/home |date=November 23, 2008 }}</ref>
A spokesman for the [[Canadian Taxpayers Federation]] has criticized the CAW's "no-concession" stance, saying that it only serves to strengthen the opposition to a taxpayer-funded bailout for the struggling Detroit Three automakers. The CTF further pointed out that "It is especially difficult to understand anyone asking for government help that refuses to do anything to help itself to begin with", since they "fail to realize they've existed at the substantial largesse of taxpayers for decades".<ref>{{cite web |first=Grace |last=Macaluso |url=http://www.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=c07f9882-2f99-4479-b067-831ac302129a |title=Lewenza 'petulant' child |work=The Windsor Star |publisher=Canada.com |date=2008-01-30 |accessdate=2009-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215051012/http://www2.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=c07f9882-2f99-4479-b067-831ac302129a |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}</ref> Kelly McParland, a columnist for the [[National Post]], has suggested that "if he won't give anything, he and his members are likely to lose everything." He also said that the problem facing the North American auto industry was borne equally by management and labor alike, criticizing labor for building up pay and benefits for themselves that was as unsustainable as it was enviable, while attacking management for its short-term strategy of selling gas-guzzling trucks and sales tactics (price cuts, rebates, free gas and cash-back schemes).<ref>{{cite web|first=Kelly |last=McParland |url=http://network.nationalpost.com/np/blogs/fullcomment/archive/2008/11/19/kelly-mcparland-stop-the-revolution-the-caw-wants-to-get-off.aspx |title=Kelly McParland: Stop the revolution, the CAW wants to get off |publisher=National Post |date=November 19, 2008 |accessdate=2009-01-12 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The CTF has opposed the proposed $3.5 CAD billion bailout for Canadian subsidiaries of the Big Three, saying that it was an unfair financial burden on the average Canadian, as well as another excuse for the Detroit automakers to postpone much needed change. The CTF noted that federal and provincial governments spent $782-million in the past five years on the Big Three, saying "These have been a bottomless pit of requests for cash". Lewenza disagreed, saying that the bailout should be seen by Canadians as a loan that will be paid back when the country's economy is prosperous again.<ref>{{cite news|first=Linda |last=Nguyen |url=https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/story.html?id=1073285 |title=Canadian taxpayers and auto union butt heads over bailout |agency=Canwest News Service |publisher=National Post |date=2008-12-13 |accessdate=2009-01-12 |df= }}{{dead link|date=January 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
On December 20, the government of Canada and the province of [[Ontario]] offered $3.3 billion in loans to the auto industry. Under the plan [[General Motors|GM]] will receive $3 billion and [[Chrysler]] will receive the rest. [[Ford]] only asked for a line of credit but will not be participating in the bailout.<ref>{{cite news|last=Austen |first=Ian |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/21/business/worldbusiness/21canada.html?ref=business |title=Canada Agrees to Its Own Auto Industry Bailout |location=Canada |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2008-12-20 |accessdate=2009-01-12}}</ref>
The CAW negotiated a cost-cutting deal with General Motors Canada on March 8, 2009. The deal would extend the current contract for an additional year to September 2012, and preserves the current average assembly-worker base pay of about $34 an hour. It would eliminate a $1,700 annual "special bonus," and reduce special paid absences or "SPA days" from two weeks to one week a year, while maintaining vacation entitlements which range up to six weeks a year for high-seniority workers. The deal also introduce payments by members toward their health benefits - $30 monthly per family for workers and $15 a month for pensioners. Lewenza said it also would trim by 35 per cent company contributions to union-provided programs such as child care and wellness programs. Lewenza called the package a "major sacrifice." However, observers noted that the deal did not go far enough; DBRS analyst Kam Hon described it as "not material." Automotive industry consultant [[Dennis DesRosiers]] said that General Motors had missed the chance to slash labour costs,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lfpress.ca/newsstand/CityandRegion/2009/03/09/8687446.html |title=London Free Press - City & Region - GM missed the boat, auto analyst says |publisher=Lfpress.ca |date=2009-03-09 |accessdate=2009-05-01}}{{dead link|date=November 2009}}</ref> pointing out that bankruptcy was a looming threat, Ottawa and Queen's Park demanded cuts to the labour bill as a condition of the bailout, and that the deficit to the pension fund would prevent the CAW from striking.<ref name="business.theglobeandmail.com"/> He estimated the total hourly cost of a GM Canada worker, including benefits, is $75 to $78, and saying that "they [GM] got six or seven" when it should have been cut by $20. DesRosiers also said giving up cost-of-living increases is not significant when inflation is nearly non-existent and added that the 40-hour reduction in [[paid time off]] merely means "five fewer spa days." [[University of Toronto]] professor Joe D'Cruz calculated that it would save $148 million a year, though GM is seeking $6 billion in Canadian government support. <ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5hj8fbrVBMQeu70Pw38EaSxlnTpsg ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313013144/https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5hj8fbrVBMQeu70Pw38EaSxlnTpsg |date=March 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.am770chqr.com/News/Business/Article.aspx?id=92681 |title=AM 770: News. Talk. Sports. - Business News |publisher=Am770chqr.com |date= |accessdate=2009-05-01 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> CAW autoworkers with seniority were able to maintain 10 weeks of vacation with full pay, while not contributing to their pension fund, relying instead on taxpayers (including these without pensions) to help make up their unfunded liabilities.<ref name="financialpost2">{{cite web |author=national post Published: Thursday, March 05, 2009 |url=http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1357929 |title=Only CAW can save Ottawa from bailout |publisher=Financialpost.com |date=2009-03-05 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090410073430/http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1357929 |archivedate=2009-04-10 |df= }}</ref>
The agreement is contingent on Canada being allocated 20% of GM's North American, and getting billions of dollars in federal and provincial taxpayer support, which Lewenza stressed will be loans. However, some suggested that this would not be the final time that automakers would request a bailout.<ref name="financialpost1">{{cite web |url=http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1343240 |title=John Ivison: Automotive bailout must not be free ride |publisher=Financialpost.com |date=2009-03-02 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402161023/http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=1343240 |archivedate=2009-04-02 |df= }}</ref> Dennis DesRosiers estimated that GM will go through its government loans in a couple of quarters, long before any recovery in the market. Furthermore, GM Canada president Arturo Elias had admitted to MP [[Frank Valeriote]] that GM had pledged all its assets worldwide to the U.S. government in order to secure the first [[tranche]] of a US$30-billion loan, leaving no assets to collateralize the $6 billion loan from the Canadian government. The Canadian Taxpayers' Federation noted that between 1982 and 2005, Ottawa handed out over $18.2 billion to corporations, of which only $7.1 billion was repayable, and only $1.3 billion was ever repaid. <ref name="financialpost2"/>
Chrysler vice-chairman and president [[Thomas W. LaSorda]] (himself the son of a CAW official) and Ford's chief of manufacturing Joe Hinrichs said that the GM-CAW deal was insufficient, suggesting that they would break the CAW's negotiating pattern set by GM. LaSorda told the [[House of Commons of Canada]] finance committee that he would demand an hourly wage cut of $20, suggested that Chrysler may withdraw from Canada if it fails to achieve more substantial cost savings from the CAW. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/CAWkeen+extend+GMdeal+Ford+Chrysler/1394268/story.html |title=CAWkeen to extend GMdeal to Ford, Chrysler |publisher=Canada.com |date=2009-03-15 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128214155/http://www.canada.com/CAWkeen+extend+GMdeal+Ford+Chrysler/1394268/story.html |archivedate=2016-01-28 |df= }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=atjPPT9kXqAY&refer=home |title=GM Says CAW Union Pact Wins Parity With U.S. Foreign Automakers |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date=2009-03-14 |accessdate=2009-05-01}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/privateEquity/idUSN1650804820090316 |title=RPT-Chrysler Canada cannot afford GM-CAW deal -source | Deals | Private Capital |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-03-16 |accessdate=2009-05-01}}</ref>
On March 31, 2009, the Canadian federal and Ontario governments jointly rejected the restructuring plans submitted by GM and Chrysler. This came a day after US President [[Barack Obama]] had rejected the plans of their parent companies. Both federal Industry Minister [[Tony Clement]] and Ontario Premier [[Dalton McGuinty]] suggested the CAW's initial deal was insufficient in cutting costs and the union had return to the bargaining table to make further concessions, in order to show that taxpayers' money is justified. <ref>{{cite web|author=Greg Keenan And Karen Howlett |url=http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090331.wgm0331/BNStory/Business/home |title=reportonbusiness.com: Find more cuts, Premier tells GM and CAW |publisher=Business.theglobeandmail.com |date=2009-03-31 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090403150353/http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090331.wgm0331/BNStory/Business/home |archivedate=2009-04-03 |df= }}</ref> As well, [[Fiat]] CEO [[Sergio Marchionne]] has asked that the CAW's wages be reduced to the levels of non-unionized workers from Honda and Toyota operating in Canada, or else they would walk away from the [[Fiat#Partnership with Chrysler|proposed alliance with Chrysler]], resulting in the latter being forced into bankruptcy.<ref>{{cite web |author=Eric Reguly And Greg Keenan |url=http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090414.wrfiat15/BNStory/Business/home |title=reportonbusiness.com: Fiat to Chrysler: Cut costs or we walk |location=Rome And Toronto |publisher=Business.theglobeandmail.com |date=2009-04-15 |accessdate=2009-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418172951/http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20090414.wrfiat15/BNStory/Business/home |archivedate=2009-04-18 |df= }}</ref>
On May 14, 2018, the Canadian federal government announced it would fall short of breaking even from the bailouts of Chrysler Group LLC and General Motors Co. by $3.5 billion.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/canadian-taxpayers-lose-35-billion-on-2009-bailout-of-auto-firms/article23828543/|title=Canadian taxpayers lose $3.5-billion on 2009 bailout of auto firms|publisher=''The Globe and Mail''|date=May 14, 2018|last=Siu|first=Michelle|accessdate=2018-06-29}}</ref> On June 26, 2018, the remaining undisclosed loan amount was written off.<ref name="CBC180626">{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/loans-canada-account-finance-auto-sector-bailout-2009-gm-chrysler-1.4722529|title=Federal government quietly writes off loan — but won't reveal sum or say who got it|publisher=''CBC News''|date=June 26, 2018|last=Beeby|first=Dean|accessdate=2018-06-29}}</ref> The [[Fraser Institute]] estimates the total cost to taxpayers at $3.7 billion that was never repaid.<ref name="CBC180626" />

{{Infobox Pro Gaming player | ID = HeatoN | name = Emil Christensen | logo = Emil Christensen.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1984|6|14}} | birth_place = [[Stockholm]] | nickname = HeatoN | status = Retired | hometown = [[Stockholm]] | nationality = [[Sweden|Swedish]] | role = Manager | leagues = The CGS, CPL | years = 2001-2008 | games = ''[[Counter-Strike]]'' | NetWorth= | years1 = 2001–2002 | team1 = [[Ninjas in Pyjamas]] | years2 = 2002–2004 | team2 = [[SK Gaming]] | years3 = 2005–2007 | team3 = Ninjas in Pyjamas | years4 = September 2007 | team4 = Ninjas in Pyjamas (''Coach'') | years5 =2007–2008 | team5 = [[Stockholm Magnetik]] (''General Manager'') | years6 = 2012–Present | team6 = [[Ninjas in Pyjamas]] (''General Manager'') }} '''Emil Pathric William Christensen''' (born 14 June 1984 in [[Stockholm]]), known as '''HeatoN''', is an [[esports]] manager and former [[Sweden|Swedish]] professional ''[[Counter-Strike]]'' player, formerly playing as captain of the gaming team [[Ninjas in Pyjamas]] (NiP). HeatoN was the manager of NiP up until October 2018 when he decided to part ways with the organisation to focus on his own brand. He is widely considered one of the best ''Counter-Strike'' players of all time.
==Career== The name HeatoN comes from a brand of equipment, which is now owned by [[CCM (ice hockey)|CCM]], he used when he played [[ice hockey]]. Emil's first hobby was ice hockey, but he retired because of an injury. A friend (CS player fRa1L, from RevolutioN) told him to try Counter-Strike. Christensen was part of the original Ninjas in Pyjamas team of 2001 which won the [[Cyberathlete Professional League]] World Championship that year. He and the other members of Ninjas in Pyjamas went on to become the foundation to the highly successful [[SK Gaming|SK Sweden]], one of the most successful teams in [[electronic sports]] history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://pcgames.gwn.com/news/story.php/id/2951 |title=pcgames.gwn.com |publisher=pcgames.gwn.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141213032116/http://pcgames.gwn.com/news/story.php/id/2951 |archivedate=13 December 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Christensen led SK Gaming to the [[World Cyber Games]] Counter-Strike championship in 2003 and to 4th place in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wcg.com/6th/tournament/2003/tm_match_medalist_cs.asp?sort=G041108114 |title=WCG Official Website |publisher=Wcg.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302124000/http://www.wcg.com/6th/tournament/2003/tm_match_medalist_cs.asp?sort=G041108114 |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wcg.com/6th/tournament/2004/tm_match_single_cs.html |title=WCG Official Website |publisher=Wcg.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302124007/http://www.wcg.com/6th/tournament/2004/tm_match_single_cs.html |archivedate=2 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
HeatoN and NiP competed in the [[World Series of Video Games]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/19618154/ns/technology_and_science-games/t/video-gamers-try-bust-lazy-boy-image/#.Vl0ZNXYrLIU|title=video-gamers-try-bust-lazy-boy-image|first=Will |last=Graves|date=July 5, 2007|accessdate=December 1, 2015}}</ref>
Christensen was nominated for Best Counter-Strike Player of the Year in 2004, losing out to SK Gaming teammate, Tommy "potti'" Ingemarsson.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esports-award.org/history/nominees2004/ |title=eSports Journalist Award :: |publisher=Esports-award.org |date= |accessdate=2013-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223101106/http://www.esports-award.org/history/nominees2004/ |archivedate=23 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> He was selected for the Global Gaming League European Counter-Strike All-Star team in 2005.<ref>[http://www.gotfrag.com/cs/story/28281/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070313112337/http://www.gotfrag.com/cs/story/28281/ |date=13 March 2007 }}</ref>
At the beginning of 2005 he and the rest of SK Sweden chose not to renew their contracts with SK Gaming and re-formed NiP.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sk-gaming.com/scene/6874/ |title=Counter-Strike: The Ninjas Are Back |publisher=SK Gaming |date=1 January 2005 |accessdate=2013-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927001115/http://www.sk-gaming.com/scene/6874/ |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Since then some of the NiP players moved back to SK Gaming but Christensen and others have stayed on at Ninjas in Pyjamas. NiP are now competing at professional LAN tournaments again, after a hiatus in which SpawN joined after HeatoN decided to take time off for personal reasons.
Christensen, along with the other members of Ninjas in Pyjamas, assisted in the design of the SteelSound 5H (USB) Headphones produced by [[SteelSeries]].
In December 2006 he travelled to New York and Dallas to provide support for his teammates as they competed in the [[World Series of Video Games]] (WSVG) world finals and CPL winter respectively. NiP were expected to be strong contenders in both tournaments, however bowed out uncharacteristically early.
In September 2007 HeatoN quit playing ''Counter-Strike'' to be coach of NiP but was then offered a chance to be a general manager for Stockholm in the [[Championship Gaming Series]] (CGS). HeatoN's CGS franchise was called the [[Stockholm Magnetik]] and had a ''[[Counter-Strike: Source]]'' team, one male and one female ''[[Dead or Alive 4]]'' player, a ''[[FIFA 08]]'' player, and two ''[[Forza Motorsport 2]]'' players.
After the CGS's folding in late 2008 Christensen moved to promote a [[computer hardware]] company named Qpad,<ref>[http://www.qpadusa.com/news/5/HeatoN_Signs_With_QPAD ]{{dead link|date=January 2013}}</ref> from his native country Sweden, for the first part of 2009. Later in the year however, he left Qpad to join with his former teammate Abdisamad "SpawN" Mohamed in product development at ZOWIE GEAR which is a manufacturer of competitive gaming gear, founded late 2008.<ref>[http://www.zowiegear.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=72&Itemid=2 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928010020/http://www.zowiegear.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=72&Itemid=2 |date=28 September 2009 }}</ref> In July 2010, ZOWIE GEAR announced HeatoN's first series of mice co-developed by himself called EC after player's initials.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zowiegear.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=130&Itemid=2 |title=South America W2B |publisher=Zowie Gear |date= |accessdate=2013-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130114215720/http://www.zowiegear.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=130&Itemid=2 |archivedate=14 January 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In March 2012 ZOWIE GEAR announced a new version of the EC series, named the EC eVo series which features an improved optical sensor and was released in April.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zowiegear.com/component/content/article/216-introducing-the-ec-evo |title=Introducing the EC eVo |publisher=Zowie Gear |date= |accessdate=2013-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121125064942/http://www.zowiegear.com/component/content/article/216-introducing-the-ec-evo |archivedate=25 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2012 Christensen returned to Ninjas in Pyjamas and became the organization's manager.
In September 2015 Christensen and two other formers NiP owners were charged with misleading an [[Financial audit|auditor]] about Ninjas in Pyjamas AB's finances during its sale to [[Diglife]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/counter-strike-nip-heaton/|title=Counter-Strike legend may face jail time|first=Jared|last=Wynne|website=The Daily Dot|date=September 29, 2015|accessdate=November 12, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111064032/http://www.dailydot.com/esports/counter-strike-nip-heaton/|archive-date=11 January 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Christensen was found guilty of [[fraud]], and was sentenced pay a fine and perform [[community service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/heaton-sentenced-accounting-fraud/|title=Counter-Strike legend HeatoN guilty of carelessness in accounting fraud case, avoids jail time|first=Samuel|last=Lingle|website=The Daily Dot|date=October 30, 2015|accessdate=November 12, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111064032/http://www.dailydot.com/esports/heaton-sentenced-accounting-fraud/|archive-date=11 January 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In June 2016 HeatoN became the first person inducted into the [[ESL Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailydot.com/esports/heaton-counter-strike-esports-hall-of-fame/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=30 June 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160630050356/http://www.dailydot.com/esports/heaton-counter-strike-esports-hall-of-fame/ |archive-date=30 June 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Professional teams== Christensen has played professionally with the following teams: *2001–2002: [[Ninjas in Pyjamas]] *2002–2004: [[SK Gaming]] *2005–2007: Ninjas in Pyjamas *2007–2007 September: Ninjas in Pyjamas (coach) *2007–2008: [[Stockholm Magnetik]] General Manager *2012–Present: [[Ninjas in Pyjamas]] Head Manager

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Frank Timiș |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Vasile Frank Timiș |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1963|1|28}} |birth_place = [[Borşa]], Romania |death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> |death_place = |body_discovered = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |nationality = |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = Industrialist, Natural Resources |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |height = |weight = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |party = |opponents = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |partner = |children = |parents = |relations = |callsign = |signature = |website = |footnotes = |box_width = }} '''Vasile Frank Timiș''' (born 1964)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/markets/article-23794488-ex-regal-boss-frank-timis-ready-to-mine-another-rich-seam.do|title=Ex-Regal boss Frank Timis set for another rich seam|last=Blackhurst|first=Chris|date=13 January 2010|publisher=London Evening Standard|accessdate=14 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619152023/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/markets/article-23794488-ex-regal-boss-frank-timis-ready-to-mine-another-rich-seam.do|archivedate=19 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> is a [[Romanian-Australian]] businessman living in London, with interests in mining and oil extraction industries. The [[Sunday Times Rich List|''Sunday Times'' Rich List]] estimated his wealth at £162m (U$238m) {{as of|2008|4|lc=on}}, making him the 497th richest person in Britain.<ref>{{citation | url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/specials/rich_list/article3769825.ece | title=Frank Timis – Sunday Times Rich List | journal=The Sunday Times | date=27 April 2008 | location=London}}</ref> The Romanian magazine ''Capital'' reckoned Timiș to be the 9th richest [[Romanians|Romanian]], estimating his wealth at $290m {{as of|2006|lc=on}}. In 2012 he became the richest Romanian with a net worth of £1.34 billion (US$2.13 billion).
==Early life==
Born in [[Borşa|Borșa]], [[Maramureş County|Maramureș County]], he graduated from a [[vocational school]] for [[auto mechanic]]s. He left [[Romania]] and settled as a refugee in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], Australia.<ref name="centrul">Centrul Român pentru Jurnalism de Investigaţii [http://www.crji.org/arhiva/e_020522.htm "Vasile Frank Timiş, the Mastermind Behind the 'Roşia Montană' Operation"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060623075309/http://www.crji.org/arhiva/e_020522.htm |date=23 June 2006 }}</ref> Whilst in Australia he was convicted of possession of heroin with intent to supply and fined A$27,000.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/chairman-of-oil-company-has-convictions-for-heroin-dealing-613881.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title = Chairman of oil company has convictions for heroin dealing }}</ref>
==Career==
===Companies in Australia===
Timiș started his own transport company in Australia, which owned only one truck driven by himself. However, it went bankrupt in 1986 with debts of 15,806 AUD. According to [[Jurnalul Naţional|Jurnalul Național]], Timiș failed to declare this fact in the CV he published when he listed the company [[Gabriel Resources]] on the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]], as required by law.<ref name="jurnalul">Radu, Paul Christian, [[Jurnalul National]], [http://www.jurnalul.ro/articol.php?id=828 "Viaţa secretǎ a lui Vasile Frank Timiş"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061115025127/http://www.jurnalul.ro/articol.php?id=828 |date=15 November 2006 }} 23 June 2005 [http://www.rosiamontana.org/documents/english/secretfrank2005.htm (English translation)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928071202/http://www.rosiamontana.org/documents/english/secretfrank2005.htm |date=28 September 2007 }}</ref>
In 1992, he became the CEO of Morwest Holdings Pty Ltd, the first of his gold mining businesses. Timiș and two Australian miners dug for six months for gold in a region called [[Mosquito Creek (Australia)|Mosquito Creek]], but the result was a failure. In the meantime, he founded another three companies: Riverdale Mining, Timis Corporation, and Carpathian Investments, together with Ioana Timiș and his sister, Ioana Majdik. However, these companies were liquidated by Timiș, and all creditors were paid in full.<ref name="jurnalul"/>
Another setback was Timiș' investment in Pneumatic Systems International Pty Ltd. In 2001, he quit his investment and kept only 11.6% of the company, administered via a new company, Regal Group Services, in the [[British Virgin Islands]] [[tax haven]]. According to an ex-manager of the company, in 2003, those shares were worth under $1,500 AUD.<ref name="jurnalul"/>
Regal Group Services changed its name and headquarters, and is currently listed on the London Stock Exchange as [[Regal Petroleum]]. This company is associated with a Romanian company, Global Mineral Resources, owned by a son of a former Romanian senator of the [[Democratic Party (Romania)|Democratic Party]], [[Teodor Hăucă]], who used to be secretary of the Economic Commission of the Romanian Senate between 1996 and 2000.<ref name="jurnalul"/>
===Gabriel Resources=== {{main article|Gabriel Resources|Roşia Montană}}
In 1995, Timiș founded Gabriel Resources NL Australia, and in the autumn of the same year, the Romanian state-owned mining company "Regia Autonomă a Cuprului din [[Deva, Romania|Deva]]" (RAC) announced that it was searching for a partnership with a foreign company for the mining of [[precious metals]] from the [[tailings]] in [[Roşia Montană|Roșia Montană]] and [[Gurabarză-Brad]]. However, [[Jurnalul Naţional|Jurnalul Național]] claims that it has documents indicating a collaboration signed by RAC Deva and Gabriel Resources one day before the announcement was published, on 4 September 1995.<ref name="jurnalul"/> Also, RAC claimed it received several offers, including from another Australian company, Lycopodium Pty Ltd., but that company has denied RAC's claim.<ref name="jurnalul"/>
According to ASIC, in April 1996, Gabriel Resources NL had financial problems with its creditors, including the [[National Australia Bank]] Ltd, and Timiș started a new company after paying all creditors in full, Gabriel Resources Limited, registered in the Jersey tax haven. The mining contract was redirected to the new company.<ref name="jurnalul"/> Timiș had an 80% stake in the joint company. The Romanian Agency of Mineral Resources declared that the new contract was unfavourable to the Romanian state, but it was allowed by the Government after a parliamentary vote.<ref name="catavencu">[[Academia Caţavencu]], [http://www.hotnews.ro/articol_20433-Frank-Timis-a-inhatat-aurul-din-Apuseni-printr-o-caruta-de-falsuri-iar-Tariceanu-a-inchis-ochii.htm "Frank Timis a inhatat aurul din Apuseni printr-o caruta de falsuri, iar Tariceanu a inchis ochii"] 19 April 2005</ref>
Timiș had access to various databanks of the Romanian research institutes of mineralogy and got data on the area. His company also hired relevant scientists and an ex-officer of the Topographic Department of the Romanian Ministry of Defence who mapped the area.<ref name="catavencu"/>
Gabriel Resources sent 80 tonnes of ore to a research lab in Australia to measure the gold content. The ore was high in gold, and the market value of Gabriel Resources soared to $75 million. Timiș obtained a $3 million loan from the [[N M Rothschild & Sons|Rothschild]] bank in the United States. Between 1999–2000, the area being mined was increased from 12 km² to 22 km², and then to 42.8 km².<ref name="catavencu"/>
The resulting project in [[Rosia Montana|Roșia Montana]] has been a source of much controversy, with local people lining up on both sides of the issue, and some national and international environmental groups joining the opposition. One source of controversy involved the method used for mining, [[gold cyanidation]], which causes pollution. The company hopes to eventually extract 300 tonnes of gold and 1600 tonnes of silver from the area but the project is currently on hold.
===Regal Petroleum=== {{main article|Regal Petroleum}}
Regal Petroleum, founded by Timiș in November 1996, was listed on the London [[Alternative Investment Market]] and owned some oil and gas resources in Romania and Ukraine. However, it became famous after the September 2003 acquisition of 60% of an oilfield located in [[Kavala]], Greece. The Regal board hoped that the company's survey team had found one of the largest oil deposits in Europe: up to a billion barrels. The oil was allegedly under so much pressure that it almost destroyed the drilling platform.<ref name="SundayTimes">[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]] 22 May 2005 [http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/business/article134708.ece "Focus: The gusher"]</ref>
This hype drove Regal's share price up to a peak of 509p, with the company's [[market value]] reaching £500m, making it one of the highest-valued companies of the Alternative Investment Market. Many private investors and respectable institutions (including [[Merrill Lynch]], [[Commerzbank]], Artemis and [[Schroders]]) invested more than £45m in the company. Days later, Timiș secretly agreed to sell the company's assets<ref>[http://business.guardian.co.uk/story/0,3604,1510911,00.html "New Regal shock as ex-chairman's secret sell-off deal is revealed"] 21 June 2005</ref> and the resigned as chief executive of the company.<ref>[[The Guardian]], [http://business.guardian.co.uk/story/0,3604,1501503,00.html "Regal chairman resigns "] 8 June 2005</ref>
By mid-2005, it was clear that Regal's oil field contained oil but not in commercial amounts. The flow rates were around 30 barrels a day and "deemed to be non-commercial".<ref name="SundayTimes"/> In a few hours, the stock fell by more than 60%, and as of June 2006, the share price was at 65p, less than 20% of the peak price. In 2010, the company was still worth about £200m, and had cash reserves of £80m,<ref>[http://www.citywire.co.uk/News/NewsArticle.aspx?VersionID=83185&MenuKey=News.Home "Regal losses widen after 'difficult' year"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 27 June 2006</ref> In February 2006, Regal lost its Ukraine gas production license in a trial but got it back through appeal one year later.<ref>[[The Guardian]], [https://www.theguardian.com/oil/story/0,,1699352,00.html]</ref>
In June 2005, an environmental group, Alburnus Maior, asked the Romanian Supreme Court, under the freedom of information laws, whether Timiș was under any investigations. The answer was that his name was linked with three dossiers investigated by the organised crime department. However, Timiș denied all the claims and no charges were ever filed.<ref>[[The Independent]], [http://www.rosiamontana.org/documents/english/press/indy2005.htm "Regal's Timis named in Romania organised crime investigation"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928071219/http://www.rosiamontana.org/documents/english/press/indy2005.htm |date=28 September 2007 }} 6 June 2005</ref> Later queries to the Romanian administration on this subject were given the answer that there are no investigations concerning Timiș.<ref>[[Averea]], [http://www.hotnews.ro/articol_23909-Dosarele-lui-Frank-Timis-s-au-evaporat.htm "Dosarele lui Frank Timis s-au evaporat"] 6 June 2005</ref>
Due to the collapse in the share price of this company, the Alternative Investment Market decided in 2006 to toughen regulations for companies in the natural resources sector and to hire experts who would prevent future bubbles followed by price fluctuations.<ref>Accountancy Age, [http://www.accountancyage.com/accountancyage/news/2158341/aim-recruits-beef-rules AIM recruits to beef up rules"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823174041/http://www.accountancyage.com/accountancyage/news/2158341/aim-recruits-beef-rules |date=23 August 2006 }} 15 June 2006</ref>
The company has, however, recently been given back licences that had been frozen by the government, and has begun to produce oil again.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
===African Minerals (AMI.L, was Sierra Leone Diamond Corporation)=== In 2005, the Timiș Trust bought 30% of the shares of the Sierra Leone Diamond Corporation, via the Trust's Bermuda-registered Timis Diamond Corporation Limited. SLDC holds mineral rights over a third of the area of [[Sierra Leone]] in the northern part of the country,<ref>Awareness Times Newspaper, Sierra Leone [http://news.sl/drwebsite/publish/article_200575.shtml "Romanian buys more Sierra Leone Diamonds shares"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060618183850/http://news.sl/drwebsite/publish/article_200575.shtml |date=18 June 2006 }}, 22 July 2005</ref> including some important diamond fields and the Tonkolili & Marampa Iron Ore Projects. The company is also exploring for uranium at Lovetta, and for gold and base metals in the [[Sula Mountains]], Gori Hills and Nimini Hills. On 16 August 2007 the [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]]-listed company was renamed African Minerals Limited (AMI.L) to reflect these other interests.,<ref>London Stock Exchange RNS, [http://www.londonstockexchange.com/LSECWS/IFSPages/MarketNewsPopup.aspx?id=1555088 Change of Name]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> On 15 March 2010 AMI announced an initial Mineral Resource estimate of over 10 billion tonnes of iron ore (independently valued) at an average grade of 29.9% Total Iron in the Numbara and Simbili targets at Tonkolili.<ref>{{citation | url=http://www.londonstockexchange.com/LSECWS/IFSPages/MarketNewsPopup.aspx?id=2081364&source=RNS | title= 4.7 Billion Tonne Initial Resource Estimate Confirms Tonkolili Iron Ore Project As World Class | publisher=London Stock Exchange | last=African Minerals Limited | date=2 February 2009 | accessdate=2 February 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
Timiș, who is executive chairman of the company, increased his shareholding to 34% in June 2006<ref>London Stock Exchange RNS, [http://www.londonstockexchange.com/LSECWS/IFSPages/MarketNewsPopup.aspx?id=1251501 Directors Share Dealings]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, 29 June 2006</ref> and to 34.6% (40,875,002 shares) in September 2006.<ref>London Stock Exchange RNS, [http://www.londonstockexchange.com/LSECWS/IFSPages/MarketNewsPopup.aspx?id=1308488 Directors Share Dealings]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, 29 September 2006</ref> {{As of|2009|02}} the entire company was worth £45m (US$65m).
In 2015, Frank Timis together with then CEO Alan Watling and CFO Matthew Hird took African Minerals into administration. The company has been forced to sell its 75% share to Shandong Iron and Steel Group for a grossly undervalued sum. Half year results for AMI were impressive, the Company posted a quarterly production of 4mt – an improvement of 81% on the prior 3 months. In January 2014 AMI hit its operating capacity for the first time, producing 5.3mt and exporting 4.6mt in the first quarter. Earnings for the Company were US$203m in 2013 compared with a US$26.5m in 2012. Despite the best efforts of the team and management, the continued downturn in iron ore prices, slowing global growth and China’s appetite and the Ebola crisis (which infected almost 15,000 and claimed 4,000 lives) left AMI exposed. The downturn in iron ore prices from US$128.12 in January 2014 decreased rapidly over coming months reaching US$68 in December 2014 and US$63 in February 2015. This combined with the Ebola crises created a perfect storm for the beleaguered mining company. Shandong refused to release remaining funds (US$100m) and their lawyers Linklater’s recognised a perfect opportunity to take over buying 75% of AMI shares at a grossly undervalued price and through a process that was anything but transparent. The Board, management and Timis fought passionately to keep the company from going to administration, but given the perfect storm it was facing and like many other junior mining Companies then and since, there was no alternative but administration. Timis lost all of his $450m investment as did the institution investors, shareholders and bond holders. AMI is now operating as Shan Steel under Chinese leadership.
=== African Petroleum === Timiș was formerly the non-executive chairman of African Petroleum, he stepped off the board and any role in Governance in African Petroleum in October 2014 and this remained a precondition of the subsequent and current listing on the Oslo Bors. He remains the founder and a supportive shareholder but plays no other role<ref>{{cite web|title=Board and Management|url=http://www.africanpetroleum.com.au/about-us/board-management|accessdate=10 April 2013|author=African Petroleum}}</ref> African Petroleum Corporation is a company with various oil and gas operations in West Africa, listed on the National Stock Exchange of Australia (NSX: AOQ) and Oslo Bors (APCL).<ref>{{cite web|title=African Petroleum Corporation Limited|url=http://www.nsxa.com.au/summary/AOQ|accessdate=10 April 2013|author=National Stock Exchange of Australia}}</ref>
=== International Petroleum=== Timiș is a non-executive director at International Petroleum Limited,<ref>{{cite web|title=About International Petroleum – Board of Directors|url=http://www.internationalpetroleum.com.au/irm/content/board-of-directors.aspx?RID=173|accessdate=10 April 2013|author=International Petroleum|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130410022928/http://internationalpetroleum.com.au/irm/content/board-of-directors.aspx?RID=173|archivedate=10 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> an Australian-domiciled, NSX-listed (NSX code: IOP),<ref>{{cite web|title=International Petroleum Limited|url=http://www.nsxa.com.au/summary/IOP|accessdate=10 April 2013|author=National Stock Exchange of Australia}}</ref> oil and gas exploration and production company.
=== Pan African Minerals === Timiș is CEO of Pan African Minerals Limited, which has various operations in Africa, including exploration of a large manganese deposit at [[Tambao]] in Burkina Faso.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frank Timis' Pan African Minerals awarded rights to the large Tambao Manganese deposit in Burkina Faso|url=http://www.newstimeafrica.com/archives/27867|publisher=News Time Africa|accessdate=10 April 2013|date=17 August 2012}}</ref><ref>http://www.railpage.com.au/f-p1913774.htm#1913774</ref>
===European Goldfields=== In 2000 Frank Timiș bought 15% of [[European Goldfields]] (EGU.L),<ref>{{citation | url=http://www.egoldfields.com/goldfields/uploads/press/News_Release.pdf | format=PDF | title=FRANK V. TIMIS No. 9, Lucial Blaga Deva, Romania 2700 NEWS RELEASE June 16, 2000 | date=16 June 2000 | publisher=European Goldfields }}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> a Yukon-incorporated company listed in Toronto and on AIM that owns 95% of Hellas Gold S.A. 21% of that stake was acquired by EGU from Timiș himself in 2004 for $77.3m, paid a third in cash and two-thirds in EGU shares, taking his stake to 18.9%.<ref>{{citation |title=Oil baron strikes £40m deal | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2898153/Oil-baron-strikes-40m-deal.html |first=Edmund | last=Conway | journal=Daily Telegraph | date=26 October 2004 | location=London}}</ref> Hellas has three mining projects in Greece ([[Stratoni]], [[Skouries]] and [[Olympias]]) and two companies in Romania: 100% of the shares of European Goldfields Deva (with projects at [[Balşa|Voia]] and the [[Cainel perimeter]]) and 80% of the shares in Deva Gold, [[Certej Mine]], [[Bolcana]] and [[Băiţa-Crăciuneşti|Băița-Crăciunești]].<ref>European Goldfields Website, [http://www.egoldfields.com/goldfields/useinfo.jsp#7 Corporate Structure] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061103215104/http://www.egoldfields.com/goldfields/useinfo.jsp |date=3 November 2006 }}</ref>
He sold his entire stake in the company between January and April 2006.
== Philanthropy == Timiș and his wife Carmen Timiș are major contributors to numerous causes, particularly those focused on children. The organisations they support include Street Child of Sierra Leone, the Carmen Timiș & Lucia B. Centre for Children,<ref>{{cite web|title=Street kids welcome Carmen Timis with special song as the African Minerals Chairman's wife makes a surprise visit to Sierra Leone|url=http://www.newstimeafrica.com/archives/25915|publisher=News Time Africa|accessdate=10 April 2013|date=30 May 2012}}</ref> F.R.O.D.O. (Foundation for the Relief of Disabled Orphans), and UK charity Anorexia and Bulimia Care (ABC).<ref>{{cite web|title=Community|url=http://www.frank-timis.com/social-responsibility/community/?zsid=219180976734212|publisher=Timis Corporation|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref>
Frank also funded the restoration of a celebrated icon kept at Romania's Namaiesti Monastery, and provides financial support to a number monasteries, convents and a hermitage in Romania.<ref>{{cite web|title=Arts and Culture|url=http://www.frank-timis.com/social-responsibility/arts-and-culture/?zsid=21918056686d398|publisher=Timis Corporation|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref> On the occasion of the Heroes Double Dip swim across the English Channel by two British soldiers, Frank donated £100,000 of his personal funds to Help for Heroes, a UK charity providing practical support for service personnel wounded in recent armed conflicts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Help for Heroes|url=http://www.frank-timis.com/social-responsibility/help-for-heroes/?zsid=21918056686d398|publisher=Timis Corporation|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref>
Timiș' various companies are engaged in a variety of corporate social responsibility projects. The Timiș Corporation has formed a partnership with ProtoPharma dedicated to advancing research into treatments for both malaria<ref>{{cite web|title=African Minerals|url=http://www.european-times.com/sector/energy-basic-materials/african-minerals/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130629032641/http://www.european-times.com/sector/energy-basic-materials/african-minerals/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=29 June 2013|publisher=The European Times|accessdate=10 April 2013}}</ref> and substance abuse.<ref>{{cite web|title=London Pharma|url=http://www.frank-timis.com/social-responsibility/medical-research/london-pharma/?zsid=21918056686d398|publisher=Timis Corporation|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref> The corporation is also a major sponsor of Sparks (a UK charity funding research into childhood diseases); has funded construction of a well on school grounds in Tonkolili, Sierra Leone; and donated €100,000 to the catholic charity Don Bosco Fambul to launch the Basics Mobil project (a bus that delivers health and community services to street children in Freetown).<ref>{{cite web|title=Don Bosco Fambul, Basics Mobile|url=http://www.frank-timis.com/social-responsibility/community/don-bosco-fambul-basics-mobil/?zsid=21918056686d398|publisher=Timis Corporation|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref>
Timiș' company African Petroleum has partnered with Sightsavers to fund training for 18 cataract surgeons, ophthalmic nurses and ophthalmologists to work throughout West Africa.<ref>{{cite web|title=African Petroleum Corporation|url=http://www.sightsavers.org/get_involved/companies/our_corporate_partners/19173.html|publisher=Sightsavers|accessdate=26 April 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130209073513/http://www.sightsavers.org/get_involved/companies/our_corporate_partners/19173.html|archive-date=9 February 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Sister company African Minerals funds Sierra Leone's national football team, the Leone Stars.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leone Stars|url=http://www.frank-timis.com/social-responsibility/community/leone-stars/?zsid=21918056686d398|publisher=Timis Corporation|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref> Also, Timiș' International Petroleum is a significant sponsor of the Kazakh National Ballet.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kazakh National Ballet|url=http://www.frank-timis.com/social-responsibility/arts-and-culture/kazakhstan-national-ballet/?zsid=21918056686d398|publisher=Timis Corporation|accessdate=26 April 2013}}</ref>
==Politics== In 2010, he donated £100,000 to the [[Christian Party (UK)|Christian Party]] for the [[United Kingdom General Election, 2010|United Kingdom General Election]].<ref>''Private Eye'', 1262, p.6</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} '''George Henry Birch''' (1862–1917) was an Australian businessman, best known for co-founding the [[Birch, Carroll & Coyle]] cinema chain, with [[E. J. Carroll]], Dan Carroll and Virgil Coyle.
==Early life== Birch was born in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull, Yorkshire]] in 1862,<ref name=obit>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/53821756 Personal News], ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 20 August 1917. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> but migrated to Australia as a young man, where he commenced work as a customs officer at the [[Customs House, Rockhampton|Rockhampton Customs Department]] in Queensland.<ref name=obit/>
==Hotel management career== After his marriage to Mary Ann Cannon on 3 October 1888<ref>Australia, Marriage Index (1788–1950), page 2245</ref> Birch resigned from his customs job to begin a career managing hotels, beginning with the Grand Hotel<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/52272832 Advertising: The Grand Hotel, Emu Park], G.H. Birch, ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 9 November 1888. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> in the seaside village of [[Emu Park, Queensland|Emu Park]] with his wife.<ref name=obit/>
From 1892, Birch became the lessee of the Union Hotel and Theatre Royale in Rockhampton before taking over the [[Criterion Hotel, Rockhampton|Criterion Hotel]] from 1903.<ref name=obit/>
Following his death in 1917, Birch's widow Mary successfully applied for a hotelier's licence<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/69807387 Licencing Court], ''[[The Capricornian]]'', 1 September 1917. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> enabling her to continue managing the Criterion Hotel until 1922, when she transferred the licence to Henry Prior.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/54022524 Notice of Application for Transfer of Licensed Victualler's License], ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 13 May 1922. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref>
==Entertainment career== In 1909, Birch formed a partnership with Edward "E.J" Carroll<ref>[https://ozvta.com/entrepreneurs-a-f Entrepreneurs: George H. Birch], Australian Variety Theatre Archive. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> who had been awarded the exhibition rights to show movies from J & N Tait's Moving Pictures.<ref>[http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/carroll-edward-john-5513 Carroll, Edward John(1868–1931)], A.F. Pike and Martha Rutledge, Australian Dictionary of Biography (Volume 7), 1979. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> As a result, Birch allowed Carroll to exhibit films at his hotels, forming the foundations of a fledgling business partnership with Carroll and his younger brother Dan Carroll, which ultimately led to the founding of Birch & Carroll.
===Earl's Court=== In 1910, Birch acquired the site of a previous open-air cinema in Rockhampton which was originally established by brothers Harry and [[Ben Goodson]] the previous year. When the Goodson brothers closed the site, Birch upgraded and expanded the site to accommodate 1500 patrons. It was re-opened as "Earl's Court" on 24 September 1910.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/53194198 Earl's Court], ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 24 September 1910. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref>
Following the successful launch of Earl's Court, Birch & Carroll continued their business partnership which included purchasing properties<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/53333008 Messrs Carroll & Birch], ''The Morning Bulletin'', 1 May 1914. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> and managing live entertainment.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/53302195 Birch and Carroll's Vaudeville Company], ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 13 June 1913. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref>
In 1912, Birch and Carroll began a business relationship with Townsville hotelier Virgil Coyle when Townsville's Olympia Theatre opened under their joint direction.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/62550450 Olympia Pictures], ''[[Townsville Daily Bulletin]]'', 23 November 1912. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> Coyle's name was incorporated into the business name in 1923 when his Townsville theatres were added to the chain.<ref>[http://www.townsvillebulletin.com.au/lifestyle/history/credits-roll-for-citys-openair-playhouse/news-story/04545a4841503ba055524ad8b94666dd Credits roll for city's open-air playhouse], Ian Frazer, ''[[Townsville Bulletin]]'', 1 February 215. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref>
Following his death in 1917, Birch's widow Mary, who was also a partner in the company, worked to ensure her late husband's vision of building a new enclosed theatre on the site was realised.<ref name=Earls>[https://queenslanddecoproject.com/2016/02/17/earls-court Earl's Court, Rockhampton: A Lost Art Deco cinema], 17 February 2016, Queensland Deco Project. Retrieved 26 February 2017.</ref>
Following negotiations, Birch Carroll & Coyle announced plans for the new theatre in August 1938.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/55986524 New Earl's Court Theatre: Construction Work To Start Shortly], ''[[The Morning Bulletin]]'', 10 August 1938. Retrieved 26 February 2017.</ref>
After the company engaged a Sydney-based architect of Art Deco cinemas to work alongside local Rockhampton architects, a seven-month project commenced costing £50,000. The open air theatre was transformed into an Art Deco theatre consisting of a large barn-like enclosure with a hard-top roof and a stepped, brick façade lit with neon tubing.<ref name=Earls/> The new 2500-seat Earl's Court reopened on 19 July 1939, becoming one of the biggest single-floor cinemas in Australia.<ref name=Earls/>
Earl's Court was eventually further modernised into an air conditioned twin-cinema complex which continued operating until 2000.<ref name=Earls/> When Birch Carroll & Coyle constructed the much larger multi-level six-cinema complex in North Rockhampton adjacent to [[Stockland Rockhampton|Rockhampton Shopping Fair]] in 1998, the company attempted to keep the older cinema in the city centre open. However, it struggled against the newer complex and its popularity waned, making it unviable for the company. When the old cinema closed, it ended a 90-year relationship between the site and the company.
Following the theatre's closure, [[St Andrew's Presbyterian Church, Rockhampton|St Andrew's Presbyterian Church]] purchased the building and moved into the old theatre from their heritage-listed site. The church continues to use the site for their regular Sunday services and as their main regional office.<ref>[http://rockypc.org.au/find-us Rockhampton Presbyterian Church: Find Us], Rockhampton Presbyterian Church website. Retrieved 26 February 2017.</ref>
===Wintergarden=== Following Birch's death in 1917, and after Coyle was officially incorporated into the company in 1923, the company opened a new theatre in Rockhampton, as part of a plan to add a network of Wintergarden theatres across Queensland.<ref>[http://www.qhatlas.com.au/content/regional-cinema Regional cinema], Denis Cryle, Queensland Historical Atlas, 3 November 2010. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> The Rockhampton Wintergarden Theatre opened in 1925.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/55229159 The Tropical Theatre: An Imposing Structure, Nearing Completion], ''The Morning Bulletin, 6 January 1925. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> During the official opening ceremony, it was publicly remarked that the late George Birch, who was described as "Rockhampton's grand old picture man", had always wished that Rockhampton should have a picture theatre of the Wintergarden's kind.<ref>[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/55230089 An Impressive Opening with the "First Nighters"], ''The Morning Bulletin'', 13 January 1925. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref>
==Death== After suffering from an illness, Birch died in 1917.<ref name=obit/>
==Birch Carroll and Coyle today== The company George Birch co-founded is still trading today, now branded as BCC Cinemas<ref>[https://www.bcccinemas.com.au BCC Cinemas website]. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> and operating under the umbrella of parent company [[Event Cinemas]]. BCC Cinemas-branded theatres are located throughout Queensland,<ref>[https://www.bcccinemas.com.au/Cinemas#state=QLD Cinemas: Queensland], BCC Cinemas website. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> New South Wales<ref>[https://www.bcccinemas.com.au/Cinemas#state=NSW Cinemas: New South Wales], BCC Cinemas website. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref> and the Northern Territory.<ref>[https://www.bcccinemas.com.au/Cinemas#state=NT Cinemas: Northern Territory], BCC Cinemas website. Retrieved 11 March 2017.</ref>

'''Harri Roschier''' (born 1957) [[Helsinki]] is a [[Finland|Finnish]] entrepreneur. Roschier was the CEO for [[Talentum Oyj]], a leading business-to-business media company in the [[Nordic countries]] between 1992 and 2006.<ref>{{cite news | title=Talentum Oyj Chief Executive Officer Resigns | url=https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/keyDevelopments?symbol=TTM1V.HE&pn=3 | newspaper=Reuters | date=28 July 2006 | accessdate=8 July 2011}}</ref> During the Roschier years the company became one of the fastest growing media companies in terms of revenue and market capitalization in the [[Nordic Countries]], growing from a less than €10 million to a €100 million company. After leaving Talentum Roschier joined in 2007 [[Avaus Marketing Innovations|Avaus Consulting]] - a management consultancy, marketing services and technology company. <ref>[http://www.digitoday.fi/tyo-ja-ura/2007/02/12/entiset-alaiset-ottivat-roschierin-osakkaaksi/20073675/66 Kauppalehti 12.2. 2007: Roschier joins his ex-employees in Avaus]</ref> He has also worked as a board member of [[Futurice]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.finder.fi/IT-sovelluksia,%20IT-ohjelmistoja/Futurice%20Oy/HELSINKI/management/248826 |title=Futurice Oy - management - Fonecta Finder |website=Fonecta Finder |publisher=Fonecta Oy |accessdate=January 17, 2014}}</ref>
Until 1980, Roschier competed in [[alpine skiing]], winning several medals in Finnish championships. He won the [[giant slalom]] in 1979<ref>{{cite journal | title=Roschier sai ensimmäisen SM:n suurpujottelussa | journal=Skimbaaja | volume=3 | issue=3 | pages=33 | year=1979}}</ref> and 1980.<ref>{{cite journal | title=Alppilajien SM-kilpailut | journal=Skimbaaja | volume=4 | issue=3 | pages=60 | year=1980}}</ref> In 1982 he went on to become the managing director of the Finnish alpine ski magazine [[Skimbaaja]]<ref>{{cite journal | title=Skimbaaja 1977–1987 | journal=Skimbaaja | volume=11 | issue=7 | pages=64 | year=1987}}</ref> of which he even acted as the editor-in-chief in 1989. After selling the publishing company to [[Sanoma]] Oyj, he worked for some time for the special interest title publishing unit within Sanoma, before becoming the CEO of a public company at 35. Roschier is still an active skier and passionate competitive sailor<ref>{{cite web | title=Volvo Espoo-Suursaari Race 2005 | url=http://www.espoosuursaarirace.org/tulokset/2005/ims1final2005.htm | date=12 June 2005 | accessdate=8 July 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726034843/http://www.espoosuursaarirace.org/tulokset/2005/ims1final2005.htm | archivedate=26 July 2011 | df= }}</ref> in the [[H-boat]] class and with his 45-footer Luna. In 2012 a syndicate headed by Roschier launched Luna a [[8mR]] replica based on drawings by [[Charles E. Nicholson]] from 1936. Luna came second in the 8 metre worlds in 2012 in Cowes.

A '''hire purchase''' (HP)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/h/hire-purchase.asp|title=Hire Purchase|last=Staff|first=Investopedia|date=2010-07-14|work=Investopedia|access-date=2018-02-25|language=en-US}}</ref>, known as '''installment plan''' in North America, is an arrangement whereby a customer agrees to a contract to acquire an asset by paying an initial installment (e.g. 40% of the total) and repays the balance of the price of the asset plus interest over a period of time. Other analogous practices are described as [[closed-end leasing]] or [[rent to own]].
The hire purchase agreement was developed in the [[United Kingdom]] in the 19th century to allow customers with a cash shortage to make an expensive purchase they otherwise would have to delay or forgo. For example, in cases where a buyer cannot afford to pay the asked price for an item of property as a lump sum but can afford to pay a percentage as a [[Down payment|deposit]], a hire-purchase contract allows the buyer to hire the goods for a monthly [[renting|rent]]. When a sum equal to the original full price plus interest has been paid in equal installments, the buyer may then exercise an option to buy the goods at a predetermined price (usually a nominal sum) or return the goods to the owner.
If the buyer defaults in paying the installments, the owner may repossess the goods, a vendor protection not available with unsecured-consumer-credit systems. HP is frequently advantageous to consumers because it spreads the cost of expensive items over an extended time period. Business consumers may find the different [[balance sheet]] and [[tax]]ation treatment of hire-purchased goods beneficial to their taxable income. The need for HP is reduced when consumers have collateral or other forms of credit readily available.
These contracts are most commonly used for items such as car and high value electrical goods where the purchasers are unable to pay for the goods directly.
==Standard provisions== To be valid, HP agreements must be in writing and signed by both [[parties]]. They must clearly lay out the following information in a print that all can read without effort: #a clear description of the goods #the cash price for the goods #the HP price, i.e., the total sum that must be paid to hire and then purchase the goods #the deposit #the monthly installments (most states require that the applicable interest rate is disclosed and regulate the rates and charges that can be applied in HP transactions) and #a reasonably comprehensive statement of the parties' rights (sometimes including the right to cancel the agreement during a "cooling-off" period). # The right of the hirer to terminate the contract when he feels like doing so with a valid reason.
==The seller and the owner== If the seller has the resources and the legal right to sell the goods on credit (which usually depends on a licensing system in most countries), the seller and the owner will be the same person. But most sellers prefer to receive a cash payment immediately. To achieve this, the seller transfers ownership of the goods to a Finance Company, usually at a discounted price, and it is this company that hires and sells the goods to the buyer. This introduction of a third party complicates the transaction. Suppose that the seller makes false claims as to the quality and reliability of the goods that induce the buyer to "buy". In a conventional contract of sale, the seller will be liable to the buyer if these representations prove false. But, in this instance, the seller who makes the representation is not the owner who sells the goods to the buyer only after all the installments have been paid. To combat this, some jurisdictions, including [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], make the seller and the finance house jointly and severally liable to answer for breaches of the purchase contract.
===Implied warranties and conditions to protect the hirer=== The extent to which buyers are protected varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction, but the following are usually present: #the hirer will be allowed to enjoy quiet possession of the goods, i.e. no-one will interfere with the hirer's possession during the term of this contract #the owner will be able to pass [[Title (property)|title]] to, or ownership of, the goods when the contract requires it #that the goods are of merchantable quality and fit for their purpose, save that exclusion clauses may, to a greater or lesser extent, limit the Finance Company's liability #where the goods are let by reference to a description or to a sample, what is actually supplied must correspond with the description and the sample.
==The hirer's rights== The hirer usually has the following rights: #To buy the goods at any time by giving notice to the owner and paying the balance of the HP price less a rebate (each jurisdiction has a different formula for calculating the amount of this rebate) #To return the goods to the owner—this is subject to the payment of a penalty to reflect the owner's loss of profit but subject to a maximum specified in each jurisdiction's law to strike a balance between the need for the buyer to minimize liability and the fact that the owner now has possession of an obsolescent asset of reduced value #With the consent of the owner, to assign both the benefit and the burden of the contract to a third person. The owner cannot unreasonably refuse consent where the nominated third party has good credit rating #Where the owner wrongfully repossesses the goods, either to recover the goods plus damages for loss of quiet possession or to damages representing the value of the goods lost.
==The hirer's obligations==
The hirer usually has the following obligations: #to pay the hire installment #to take reasonable care of the goods (if the hirer damages the goods by using them in a non-standard way, he or she must continue to pay the installments and, if appropriate, recompense the owner for any loss in asset value) #to inform the owner where the goods will be kept. #A hirer can sell the products if, and only if, he/she has purchased the goods finally or else not to any other third party. it is pretty much similar to installment but the main difference is of ownership.
==The owner's rights== The owner usually has the right to terminate the agreement where the hirer defaults in paying the installments or breaches any of the other terms in the agreement. This entitles the owner: #to forfeit the deposit #to retain the installments already paid and recover the balance due #to repossess the goods (which may have to be by application to a Court depending on the nature of the goods and the percentage of the total price paid) #to claim damages for any loss suffered.
==In Australia== Hire purchases are commonly used by businesses (including [[company|companies]], [[partnership]]s and [[sole trader]]s) in [[Australia]] to fund the purchase of [[cars]], [[commercial vehicles]] and other business equipment.
Under [[Australian Taxation Office]] rules, businesses who account for [[Goods and Services Tax (Australia)|GST]] on an [[accrual basis accounting|accruals basis]] are entitled to claim an [[Input Tax Credit]] for all of the [[Goods and Services Tax (Australia)|GST]] contained in the purchase price of the goods on their next [[Business Activity Statement]].
Hire purchase is also commonly known as ''commercial hire purchase'' and ''corporate hire purchase'' (both abbreviated to ''CHP'') in Australia.
==In Malaysia== Hire purchases agreement are commonly known as H.P agreement in [[Malaysia]] and it is used by [[financial institutions]] in [[Malaysia]] to fund the purchase of consumer goods, [[vehicles]] and other business equipment and industrial machinery.
In [[Malaysia]], the legislation governing hire purchase transactions is the Hire Purchase Act 1967, which came into force on 11 April 1968 after hire purchase became popular in the acquisition of expensive consumer goods such as [[cars]], business equipment and industrial machinery. Purchasing [[cars]] is the most common type of hire purchase agreement in [[Malaysia]] and the repayment could take up to 9 years from the date of agreement been executed.

'''Kurt Ove ''Håkan'' Buskhe''' (born 8 November 1963 in [[Örnsköldsvik]]) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] businessman, better known as the president and CEO of the Swedish aerospace and defence company [[Saab Group]], a role he has been in since September 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=4 krav avgjorde Saabs val av vd |url=http://www.svd.se/naringsliv/4-krav-avgjorde-saabs-val-av-vd_4621635.svd|website=SvD.se}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Han blir ny Saabchef|url=http://www.privataaffarer.se/borsguiden/han-blir-ny-saabchef-1-104481|website=PivataAffärer.se}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Håkan Buskhe|url=http://www.di.se/amnen/buskhe-hakan/|website=di.se|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923214253/http://www.di.se/amnen/buskhe-hakan/|archivedate=2015-09-23|df=}}</ref>
In addition to this role, he is also the chairman of the board of directors of Sweden’s [[state-owned]] logistics and transport company [[Green Cargo]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Hollander, Mats|title=Håkan Buskhe ny ordförande i Green Cargos styrelse |url=http://www.greencargo.com/sv/Pressrum/Nyheter/Nyhetsarkiv/Hakan-Buskhe-ny-ordforande-i-Green-Cargos-styrelse/ |website=Green Cargo}}</ref>
==Early life== Buskhe was born in 1963 in the north-east of Sweden, in Örnsköldsvik. He attended [[Chalmers University of Technology]], where he earned a [[Master of Science]] degree in science and engineering, as well as a [[Licentiate (degree)|licentiate]] in engineering, and a [[diploma]] in corporate management.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
==Career== He began his career in the military, carrying out military service during the 1980s, where he worked as a weapons technician. This gave him a basic initiation into the world of arms and defence, the only such experience he would later take into his role at Saab. His first real career move was at a logistics company called Scansped where he joined in 1988 as assistant to the [[managing director]]. He rose through the ranks of this company and became head of EDP in 1990, where he was responsible for the implementation of a transport administration IT system across [[Europe]].<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
In 1994, he moved to [[Carlsberg Group|Carlsberg]], serving in various key senior logistics roles before he moved on to the electrical wholesale company Storel in 1998, where he eventually became managing director.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref> In 2002, he became the CEO of logistics firm Schenker North, where he later became a board member in 2005.
In 2006, Bushke joined the [[Germany|German]] energy company [[E.ON]]’s Swedish division, E.ON Sverige, where he served as senior vice president before being appointed as president and CEO of the entire [[Nordic region]]. It was his successful time here that made his reputation as future candidate for Saab’s leadership.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
In September 2010, Bushke was appointed as CEO of [[Saab Group]], with the chairman [[Marcus Wallenberg (born 1956)|Marcus Wallenberg]] choosing him for his breadth of expertise and focus on the high-tech field.<ref>{{cite web|title= Håkan Buskhe |url= http://www.europeanceo.com/profiles/hakan-buskhe-saab/ |website=EuropeanCEO.com|date=18 March 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Bushke is married with three daughters. <ref>{{cite web|title=SWEDEN IS A MODEL: INTERVIEW WITH HÅKAN BUSKHE - THE CEO OF SAAB|url=http://saab.com/pt/air/gripen-fighter-system/gripen/gripen.com/Orgulho-de-ser-Brasileiro/Updates-news/filtered-stories/sweden-is-a-model/|website=Saab|date=26 February 2014}}</ref> The oldest daughter Katrine (b. 1988)<ref>{{citation|title=Sveriges befolkning 1990|year=2011|publisher=Svensk arkivinformation (SVAR), Riksarkivet|language=sv|isbn=978-91-88366-91-7}}</ref> lives in Gothenburg.

{{DISPLAYTITLE:iBRIDGES}} {{Infobox convention | name = iBRIDGES | image = IBRIDGES logo.png | alt = iBRIDGES' logo | caption = | status = Active | genre = [[Entrepreneurship]] | venue = | location = | coordinates = | country = | first = 2014 | last = | attendance = | organizer = [[Iranian diaspora]] | filing = | website = http://ibridges.org | footnotes = }} '''iBRIDGES''' is an annual convention for [[Iranian diaspora]] to meet with Iranian entrepreneurs and business people.<ref name="Bozorgmehr">{{cite web | last=Bozorgmehr | first=Najmeh | title=Iran’s tech sector to display potential in Berlin | website=[[Financial Times]] | date=2015-05-21 | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d729e71c-fed9-11e4-84b2-00144feabdc0.html | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> The primary goal of the convention is to bridge the gap between the Iranian high-tech [[Startup company|start-up]]s and the western investors.<ref name="Dehghan">{{cite web | last=Dehghan | first=Saeed Kamali | title=From Digikala to Hamijoo: the Iranian startup revolution, phase two | website=[[the Guardian]] | date=2015-05-31 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/may/31/amazon-iranian-style-digikala-other-startups-aparat-hamijoo-takhfifan | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> The discussions in this convention are intended to primarily focus on entrepreneurship opportunities in Iran's [[High tech|tech industry]] rather than its internal or foreign policies.<ref name="DW.DE 2015">{{cite web | title= Will Tehran become the Silicon Valley? | website=[[Deutsche Welle]] | date=2015-05-24 | url=http://www.dw.de/%D8%A2%DB%8C%D8%A7-%D8%AA%D9%87%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AF%D8%B1%D9%87-%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%84%DB%8C%DA%A9%D9%88%D9%86-%D8%AE%D9%88%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%AF-%D8%B4%D8%AF/a-18473912 | language=fa | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref><ref name="VOA">{{cite web | title=The largest gathering of Iranian diaspora in last 30 years will be held in Berlin| website=[[Voice of America]] | date=2015-05-21 | url=http://ir.voanews.com/content/iranians-berlin/2780930.html | language=fa | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref>
The 2014 convention in [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Brekeley]] attracted more than 700 Iranian [[high-tech]] executives and entrepreneurs.<ref name="EETimes 2010">{{cite web | last=Merritt | first=Rick | title=Entrepreneurs Seek Bridge to Iran | website=[[EE Times]] | date=2014-09-08 | url=http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1323799 | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> The 2015 convention in [[Berlin]] is called "the largest gathering of Iranians outside the country in more than three decades".<ref name="The Washingtion Times 2015">{{cite web| last=Sands | first=David R. | title=U.S. allies not waiting for Iran’s sanctions to come down | website=[[The Washington Times]] | date=2015-05-27 | url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/may/27/us-rivals-not-waiting-for-irans-sanctions-to-come-/ | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> It was held from June 4-6, 2015 at the new Berlin CityCube convention center. The event included 117 sessions with 163 speakers, and 1,040 registered participants from 35 countries. [[Dave McClure]], one of 2015 attendees, counts the large population of Iran and its educated population as potential for startups in the country.<ref name="Dehghan"/> The official final and detailed [http://ibridges.org/ibridge-berlin-2015-report/ report] of the iBridge Berlin was released by organizer in October 2015.
The convention is also implicitly aimed at bridging the gap in [[international relations]]hip between Iran and western countries,<ref name="Burrows">{{cite web | last=Burrows | first=Mathew J. | title=Diversity Is America's 21st Century Strength | website=[[The Huffington Post]] | date=2014-08-20 | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mathew-j-burrows/diversity-is-americas-21s_b_5695593.html | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> especially at the time of diplomatic negotiations between Iran and western countries on [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iran's nuclear program]].<ref name="Dehghan"/>
The next iBridge will be held on December 8-10, 2016 in Barcelona, Spain.
